150459778.review:
This is not a metroidvania. It is more akin to a (mostly) side-scrolling action RPG, with a big world and linear area progression with a bit of open-world questing and exploration in each area. Some have compared it to classic Zelda games and it's definitely got that vibe. 

Pros are nice presentation, some lovely character designs and animation work. The music mix is deceptively variable and some of the tracks are fantastic. It is a really nice world to explore, full of flavourful NPCs. This is a game I really wanted to like as it is clearly a labour of love... which may be the problem. 

Reason why I don't recommend it is combat and platforming difficulty on 'challenges'. It is not 'hard' as such, but it is unforgiving and requires a certain level of technical skill. The player is expected to experiment to learn the techniques that you won't find out about in game until after you need them (yes, you can go wiki-diving instead). Uneven difficulty jumps encountered in only the first two areas do not help. Difficulty options are available (if a bit obtuse to understand initially) but they do not help the fundamental areas that make it feel so frustrating for me. Veterans and devs have clearly spent a lot of time polishing this gem but in doing so they have overtuned things to their (high) ability. 

I have not finished this game and have given up in frustration in the second area (bandit combat trial). Yes, it is possible to 'master' the game to proceed but if you lack the technical and precise skills that this game demands then, like me, you find find it frustrating rather than challenging. If you do enjoy or are able to overlook the skill demanded then there is a lot to like. I cannot recommend it though; not without first trying a demo and seeing if the combat 'clicks' with you first, because if it doesn't, it will bar your enjoyment of the rest of this seemingly lovely game.

148702948.review:
/!\ /!\ /!\ SPOILERS /!\ /!\ /!\

This game is a masterpiece, clearly a hidden gem considering how little spotlight it had and how poorly it sold. Really a shame!
Phoenotopia looks amazing, I couldn't help myself but take dozens of screenshots while I was playing. Last time I did that was when I played Gris.

The gameplay is simply fantastic, there are tons of smart interactions in the game design, the puzzles really test your spatial perception: whether it's activating a switch by angling your slingshot the right way, using projectiles to knock moonstones off their platform, piling up boxes and bombs to gain barely enough height to reach a platform, or completing parkour sections full of arrow traps with well synchronized jumps.
The puzzles where you need to play the correct song with your flute gave me Zelda Ocarina of Time vibes. I liked how musical notes were often hidden in the background, and I had to spot them to know what I would need to play with the bandit's flute.
The GEO dungeons especially had really different kinds of puzzles. One time you'll have to solve a jigsaw puzzle, the next time it'll be a sliding picture puzzle, then it will involve switching lights in the correct order. There's even a puzzle similar to sudoku.
The game always managed to hold my attention with all its brainteasers.

Cooking mechanic is based on reaction time, it's simple and engaging. I noticed there was a frying pan on display in the Antique Shop near Daea city, but I never managed to obtain it during my playthrough. I suppose it would have modified the cooking minigame in a certain way?
Btw, I like how we immediatly drop cooked meat when we kill a mob/animal with an explosion (bomb or spear). Pretty cool that they thought about that!

The Gear Ring allows you to quickly switch up between 8 different items, it's always a good thing to have a weapon wheel in any game I play. It's very ergonomic and it saved me a lot of time from navigating through the menus.
And I'm thankful that we can use all our weapons as much as we want, without having to worry about ammo.

It's very satisfying when you struggle while exploring an area for the 1st time, having to use your gear in a clever way, dealing with all the enemies and barely surviving. And then when you revisit the same area later in the game with a new ability, you can make it through in a much simpler way. The abilities that you get for traversal exploration are really game-changing. I was so excited to backtrack everytime I got a new one.

Phoenotopia Awakening is very charming, and has a lot of light-hearted moments. I never got tired of listening to "Merry Fellowship" everytime Gail came back to her hometown after a mission, checking in with her brothers & sisters to see if they're okay. The game even manages to be funny sometimes. For example, when Gail and Fran use the teleporter for the 1st time, and Gail thinks Fran died during the teleportation as she watches the pile of dust on the ground, before Fran immediatly appears out of nowhere with a big smile on her face.
The game also managed to do the exact opposite on several occasions. I was very anxious during that moment in EDEN's Lab, when you're quietly exploring the rooms and reading notes about those harpys in their stasis chamber. As you progress, you suddently hear glass breaking, and when you turn around, you notice all the harpys broke out.

Those moments, whether tense or joyful, are always accompanied by excellent music. My personal favorites are "Merry/Mellow Fellowship", "Boss battle", "The White Towers", "Katash's theme", "Wheat Road" and "Caves of Mul".

You can't put markers on a map to remember points of interest. So I had to write down informations on a notepad regularly to not get lost and not forget things like treasure chests, entrances to dungeons, or song stones. There are tons of stuff to do and optional content, so having a quest log and a map available at all times would have been useful, but it was definitely manageable without it.

I loved the last part of the game that consists of 3 Boss fights back-to-back. The first one against Mother Computer was the most challenging fight in the entire game. Then you have this amazing showdown with your own shadows, and finally the duel vs Katash.
I have to say this last battle felt a bit anticlimactic. I had encountered Adam earlier in the lab, and I thought I would have to fight this monstrosity, but instead it was a second duel with Katash.
I'm pretty sure (and I hope) that I will have to fight Adam when I'll come back to this game to get the true ending, and I can't wait for it.

I unlocked the first ending after 60 hours with a completion of 62%. I played enough and I don't want to push myself, so I won't go for 100%. However, I will surely come back to this game in a few months to do some more things. Notably exploring Aurantia, beating Katash' 2nd encounter, and accessing the locked room at the top of Pristine City to fight Phalanx.

I don't know how they did it, but the game was never boring, never frustrating, never too hard, never too easy, never repetitive, never bad. There was the right amount of everything: fights, exploration, puzzles and platforming.
Really, as I said earlier, the only thing that people could have a problem with is that it can be difficult to keep track of everything. But it's really not that big of a deal if you pay attention, and of course if you write things down on a notepad or a piece of paper.

This is why I give this game a perfect score. This is one of the best games I've played this year! I'm still a bit salty that this game is so unknown...

10/10

Recommended only if you've got all of the patience and spare time in the world, even if it's on a deep discount. I'm a generally patient person who doesn't easily get frustrated by video games. The moment I realized that the consequence for failure in this game was going to be the old school "increasing amounts of either standing around waiting and/or grinding for healing items", I couldn't enjoy the game anymore.

Pros:
-Game is huge
-Lots of interesting and varied puzzles to solve
-Lots of nooks and crannies with goodies to find
-There's a flute you can play whenever you want
-Movement seems rough at first but you get (somewhat) used to it over time
-Unlockable items genuinely open up the world in brand new ways each time you find one
-Fishing mini game +++++
-Most bosses are enjoyable and/or cheesable if you're getting frustated

Cons:
The penalty for failure in this game is taking little bits of your time over and over and over again
-Ragdoll after hit is gratuitously long and you bounce multiple times unless you dodge-cancel the first bounce
-Tons of areas and minigames where mistiming a jump/getting hit requires you to wait/run 15-30 seconds before retrying
-Lots of later enemies cannot be staggered but can chain-stun you to death
-button-mashing QTEs when restrained will never get you free fast enough to matter
-all healing is done with food and/or a song that can heal you 99 damage (not a full heal later in the game when your health is higher) that you can't play again for *fifteen minutes*
-food has to be bought or farmed from enemies, then cooked
-average cooked food items can offset one, maybe two hits. many enemies can hit you multiple times in a row even with increased superarmor turned on in accessibility options
-limited inventory slots means you'll want to focus on upgrading your inventory ASAP or make multiple trips back to town at every opportunity to get more healing items
-besides the teleporters that get you from main region to main region, there is no fast travel (really thought all those angel statues were gonna pay off eventually)

This would've been worth a couple weekend rentals as a kid, I work full-time now and found myself getting more frustrated by this game than enjoying the time playing it. There was a time when I'd probably have put another 50 hours into this game looking for every little hidden detail/mastering the wonky physics used for movement, but at this point I'd just rather play a good game that I enjoy instead of an alright game that revels in wasting my time

What's the good?

The game made it obvious what sci-fi themes are present early on, but did decently pace other elements over time. I will say, however, the story does not end too well. Upon further reading, it appears the devs do want to continue an overarching story in another game that will likely be in development for a while... Gameplay:

This is such a fantastic little game, I'm actually really impressed that it's only $20! There's a ton of stuff in this game for such a small amount of money, and unlike the vapid, shallow padding you find in most AAA titles, this game's content is so lovingly crafted. Collectibles are cleverly hidden, and I found myself going to the fortune teller to find out more heart gems and moonstones are in that dungeon I was certain I scoured from top to bottom. The puzzles are great (though I found one or two of them were a bit TOO hard), and I found myself writing down notes and diagrams to try to figure some of them out.

And that's without even touching the story and the world-building, which is top notch in my opinion. It's involved enough to be interesting, but not so dense that it bogs itself down, it really hits that sweet spot that a lot of other titles miss. The mood is often lighthearted and wholesome, but it has a bit of a dark side too, especially when you start learning about what happened in the past. The characters and dialog are charming and delightful, I found myself falling in love with so many of them. It got to the point where, when I was told that two of the characters had been sent off to be killed, I immediately went around talking to everyone nearby to see if there was a way to save them. 

My only real gripes are with some of the controls, and maybe the symbols used for the songs. You have to use the quick select menu by moving the right stick over the item you want to equip and then clicking the right stick down to select it. It's not terrible, but it's easy to mess up when you're in a tense fight. The symbols used for playing songs aren't really intuitive, you just kind of have to memorize which symbol corresponds to which direction, which is fine once you've got it down, but even near the end of the game I was still struggling with it just a bit.

Also the sprint is a bit weird, because it's not like a Mario style game where you hold down the sprint button and you'll always be sprinting, you have to be touching the ground and if your feet leave the ground for any reason, even if you're dropping down a very small ledge, you stop sprinting and have to manually press the sprint button down again. It's not the worst ever, I was definitely able to complete all the free running challenges, and even got the Lunar Key (even if I had to watch a video of someone doing it first). In fact, I nearly got all the items in the game, save for one energy gem. I just couldn't beat the last shooting gallery challenge. Also I didn't fight the optional boss, since I figured the game is going to require me to get 100% items.

In conclusion, if you love side scrolling action/metroidvania-likes, gorgeous pixel art, and a heartwarming story and characters, this is probably your jam.

What a wonderful Zelda/Metroid adventure! In general, the game's got it all: an interesting mixed-technology world like something outta Star Ocean with an intriguing plot, charming characters with amusing dialogue that never felt cringe, refreshingly actual challenging combat and puzzles, a huge world to explore with tons of sidequests and places that give great rewards to keep track of and come back to, an addictive sense of progression with new gadgets and abilities, and so on! Like I said, it's the total package and anyone looking for a great Zelda-esque adventure should highly consider picking this up.

Some points to consider:

1) Combat works, and does have a lot of nice things to it like no old-school contact damage (enemies can only hit you with clearly telegraphed attack animations), but it can be a bit frustrating due to 1) stamina constantly running out and taking so long to regenerate 2) your melee attack being very short and stubby which forces you to get right in enemies faces to not whiff 3) no iframes, even for the dodge roll manuever, which makes defense feel very awkward 4) enemy attacks feeling overwhelming as they can send you ragdolling around and can wombo-combo you due to no post-hit invincibility. As said, it's balanced for this, there are a lot of great fights, and there are accessibility options, but even when I accepted it for what it was, it still felt so annoying at times.

2) The game doesn't have any sort of marking system or a quest log to keep track of all the stuff you're doing, so if you play this, I highly recommend you have a notepad handy like I did. I enjoyed this prospect, but it can be difficult to keep track of everything if you leave the game.

3) The cooking system seemed nice at first, but I was sick of it by the end. Cooking food is practically always a net positive compared to raw food, and there's no sense of expression through recipes or customization or whatever, so it just becomes tedium you always have to go through the motions to do, killing the pace. It's kinda like how, unlike most survival games which have cooking be a challenge at the start but eventually automate it to let you focus on greater goals, in this you always need to make time for cooking and fishing and are never free from it (some people may like this though, I suppose!)

4) The moonstone currency system can be a bit frustrating in that I thought it was only used for unlocking fast travel, but suddenly the game pulled a fast one mid-way and offers upgraded gear which costs moonstones as well, meaning I felt cheated as now I had to decide between convenience and fun in a battle where both choices felt bad until I eventually get enough stones for everything I wanted.

5) I enjoyed the journey and everything so it didn't sour me too much, but the ending did fall a bit flat to me as many things were handwaved offscreen or left unresolved.

So far i had only made it to the Ouroborous trials, so maybe later some upgrades will change some of the problems game have for the better, but, nevertheless, problems there are.

The game is very good in terms of visual design, music and exploration.

But there are many enemies, that move incredibly abruptly - and that invalidates using charge attack for anything but crushing the crates.
Second - cooking minigame. It is fun on it's own, but you either have to tediously do it with every next item, reequipping each next stack, or stay with inferior healing items.
Third - incredibly high health of many "random encounter" enemies. It is not, that you cannot just escape them, it is when you are going to get some ingredients/money from them - each of this encounters feels like it is miniboss at least.
Fourth - VERY strange dash and dash jump. Dash itself just stops, when you jump, when you fall to the lower surface, any second you are disconnected from the ground - and it does not continue/start, if you still hold dash button. More than that - it is not a modifier button as in "hold dash and right to run right", it is a movement button, that moves you in the direction, that character is faced - so, in several platforming moments, when you need to dash jump betweer branches quickly, because they break under the character, in many cases you just fly away in the wrong direction. And because of all of that, dash jump itself works equally bad.
Fifth - most enemies and enemies combinations are designed with intention to trick you - beginning with mentioned earlier  abrupt movement and attacks, followed by combination, when there is "sniper" enemies, that throw their projecties aiming at you - not just in your direction as in left-right-up-down, but actually aiming. And this enemies are usually go in packs of 2 to 4 or combined with melee's, that actively and very aggressively follow you.
Shooting is also quite questionable - aiming the crossbow just feels wrong - combined with much less predictable and abrupt movement of enemies and high stamina consumption with not that high damage against said enemies.
Towns - they are overloaded, It is cool, when there are details, when there are lore NPCs, but there are just too many of everything. Maybe developers had tried to create the effect of "lost in the city, exploring", but it just feel tedious.
So, the game itself is not that hard on it's own, yet combination of controls, enemy behaviour, overuse of minigames, too many NPCs, that look like they are quest ones, but actually not, makes this game somewhat tiring. PHoenotopia has a lot going for it: Charm, interesting story, decent characters, an enormous yet full world, lots of good puzzles, good inventory system, lots of side-quests, good pixel graphics and animation, varied monsters. But somehow, it totally sucks to play, in a way that's hard to pin down. Most obviously, the combat feels off, and there is a TON of combat. The controls feel like you're fighting your character, and struggling to get your attacks out, more than facilitating your skill. It's very hard to avoid getting pinged by the numerous traps and enemy ranged attacks, which are all over the place.

As a result, you're constantly getting drained, chipped-away at. This leads to the murkier problem: The math is just off. You take too much damage, there are too many sources of damage, and healing is too little and too far between. You have to be constantly hunting up food items, and then spend time cooking them, just to stay at a safe level of health. The inns are very few and far between, and save points don't restore you. I can easily see getting stuck in the middle of a dungeon or cave, not able to move forward or even back out, because you've run out of food, your health is low, and there's stuff just pinging you all over the place.

The end result is very strange--this seems like mostly a kids' game, by tone, by story, by graphics. But it's far too long and complex to be fun at that level, and the frustration at getting constantly battered about and desperate for health sources is far too aggravating to appeal to a young player. Even the challenges are too closely-timed, considering the muddy controls. Players, especially young players, don't like being confronted with constant failure.

It would take a nigh-total overhaul to fix this. Hopefully these problems can get tuned for another game, because what's good here is very good. But the bad makes it borderline unplayable. I found myself dreading booting the game up to take another crack at advancing; that's never a good sign.

I remember playing the original flash version of this from 2014, and I was amazed at the quality and quantity of the content. After a few years I happened upon the news of the remake and followed its development with cautious optimism, and I'm happy to say I think it turned out great. This was one of the most enjoyable games I've played recently. It was the kind of game that I enjoyed beginning to end, I was always looking forward to coming back to it. I 100%ed and then went for the finale, and I was left with that bittersweet "satisfied and happy it happened, depressed that it's over" feeling, and I went back and scoured the game for every last drop of content.

The game world is full of charm and sincerity; well animated pixel graphics and smooth weighty movement, loads of different in-game environments, lots of amusing dialogue throughout the game (more the kind that makes you smile, rather than the kind that makes you laugh), a cool setting with lots of satisfying world-building to be found in exploring, talking, and item descriptions, and a well told sincere story that is lighthearted and optimistic but also doesn't undermine itself with silliness. The game has a great balance of lightheartedness and seriousness, and the music is fantastic and catchy with loads of variety; I was always looking forward to hearing a new track in every new environment.

Puzzling and platforming gameplay are very enjoyable; there's a huge number of puzzles and challenges all over the map, lots of different types: logic puzzles, timing puzzles, riddles, some well hidden ones involving background details and such. The platforming is usually tied to the puzzles, and while it occasionally requires some dexterity, the game rarely calls for pixel-perfect finger-crunching platforming (I recognise this [i] may [/i] be seen a mark against the game). I will note however: For people who enjoy acquiring new movement abilities in metroid-vania style games; that isn't a huge feature in this game. While you [i] do [/i] acquire abilities that let you traverse more environments and move around in new ways, the majority of your character's acrobatic abilities are available to you right from the start of the game and aren't altered or upgraded significantly from their original form. 

Dungeons in-game somewhat resemble puzzle dungeons in some Zelda games, rather than the more maze-like dungeons you can find in some metroid-vania games. While the dungeons and levels have several optional off-shoots and hidden areas (and the same is true for the world map), most dungeons are fairly straightforward in design. The game lacks in-game maps, but in my opinion it doesn't need any as the dungeons aren't sprawling or confusing enough, and the cities are also often quite well signposted. The world is big enough that you might forget the exact location where you found a specific item/puzzle/room/npc you couldn't reach or interact with before, but you'll probably know which area it was in, and I'd say you are very unlikely to be completely lost at any point.

The combat gameplay is the most common point of contention in reviews, but I found it pretty enjoyable in most encounters. In my opinion, the gameplay in general feels very tightly designed, and I think that the claims of ultra-difficulty are extremely overblown; the game isn't anywhere near as crushingly difficult as many reviews (positive or negative) imply. The combat is often negatively compared to Hollow Knight (another game I enjoy), but the two games are only superficially similar, both in combat and other design and gameplay aspects. Compared to something like HK, the combat is slower paced; enemies move slower or more clumsily, both their and the player's attacks have more wind-up and wind-down, most enemies have no collision damage so you can move in closer and stay there longer, most enemies can be knocked back/interrupted if you hit them with a charged attack, there isn't any mercy invincibility after being hit so a single big strike can put you on the backfoot, and you have less aerial control than in something like HK. Then there's the stamina system where basic movement (running, jumping, crawling) costs nothing, but most other moves - sprinting, rolling, melee (both fast and charged attacks), and secondary weapons/equipment - cost stamina, and you can't be relentless with your attacks and must manage your stamina. Finally, there's healing, which typically has to be done mid combat without pausing  so you have to quickly stop and eat a healing item during a lull in the fight, with a choice between quick low healing items and slow high healing ones. 

All this combines to give the combat a slightly slower pace, so for example after a few short bursts of sprinting you'll dodge with a jump or roll, then get only a few hits and a charged hit in and run out of stamina, then focus on dodging/healing again, and so on. As you get used to the combat, you learn how best to use up your stamina and which weapons/items are most effective against different types of enemies, when you can sneak hits in during the dodging periods, and when it's best to use the faster or slower healing items. You'll rarely need to hyper-focus on intense stamina management, since most attack dodging doesn't require much (if-any) stamina so there's less pressure if you run out.  I found that most combat encounters were designed well with all this in mind, especially when alongside Gail's (the player character) really well animated and weighty movement and combat motions, so you get lots of cool and satisfying moments where you're rolling under enemy attacks, smacking multiple enemies with charged hits and sending them flying, or being sent flying yourself but using a smooth recovery cancel and getting right back to the fight.

I will say that there are a few cases where the game puts too many of one type of enemy in too tight a space or too many aerial enemies and only small platforms to stand on, so due to your relatively limited aerial control it can make for some frustrating moments where you're forced to just tank a lot of hits and burn through healing supplies fast, but these moments don't come along often and the game is reasonably generous with save points so you can usually try again pretty quickly if you fail.

The game is quite slowly paced and one could probably say that around 90% of the game is optional content, so if you don't have time for long games or you prefer to jump in and play something to completion in a shorter time, then this game is not ideal for that. I found the game to be extremely engrossing and satisfying, and if you enjoy long form games with lots of exploration and are the type to go around talking to everyone and looking at everything in games then I'd say I can recommend this to you.

I had cautiously-optimistic expectations for Phoenotopia: Awakening, and it blew those expectations out of the water. I don't understand how I haven't heard more about this game. It's a really fun, engaging, and challenging Zelda-inspired adventure with a TON to do. The playtime estimates in the official description are accurate: my first completion-ish playthrough took me 35 hours, and full completion took me a total of 55 hours.

I really enjoyed it!

- The game has a bunch of varied challenges, and they're all pretty great. Besides combat it's got logic puzzle challenges, observation challenges, jumping challenges, timing challenges. A few puzzles required me to take notes, but no puzzle was a complete stumper.

- I really enjoyed the combat, both against normal enemies and bosses. Your movement feels good to play, you get a bunch of fun tools and items, and the types of enemies you encounter are varied. I know there's plenty of folks out there who really dislike an aggressive stamina system, but I really appreciate how the stamina system makes you consider when to strike and when to back off and rest (and there does exist an accessibility setting to let you attack without using stamina, if you truly hate it). In all, the combat comes together in a super enjoyable way.

- The bosses were intimidating and challenging in a way I really enjoyed. More than once I'd fight a boss and get destroyed, and wonder how the heck I'd ever possibly be able to defeat them, only to learn their moves over another three or four attempts, and beat them without much frustration.

- The platforming's great. Running around as Gail is fun, many of your tools have traversal applications as well as combat applications. There's even a small Breath-of-the-Wild-ish aspect, where I was able to figure out how to combine my tools in interesting, probably-not-intended ways to sequence break a little, but in a way that felt like the game was rewarding me more than it felt like I was breaking the game.

- The level design is fantastic, and really elevates both the platforming and exploration. In particular the towns: every town is fairly large, but every town past the first one is dense and layered and just, very fun to run around in and search for secrets.

- There's a ton to explore. In addition to zones being dense, there's hundreds of upgrades to find, with unique quests and requirements for finding them. I was playing pretty completionist, and I only found around 2/3s of the upgrades without the use of the in-game hint system.

- The plot is on-par with a Zelda: every beat has good stakes, with plenty to keep me engaged.

- The setting and worldbuilding are very cool and deep without being overbearing.

- The characters are all fun, and the game knows when to be a little serious and when to be a little silly with them (and importantly is able to pull off both effectively).

- The pixel art is quite nice: simple and clear but intricate enough to hide cool secrets in. And the animation is very strong: it's all totally expressive, and every so often it flexes with something super impressive.

- There's a bunch of different minigames, and they're all very cute, and just the right amount of challenging and engaging. Mostly I just want to call out the cooking minigame, which you'll probably end up doing a lot. It's the perfect amount of engaging, with real risks (burning your healing items) and real rewards (better healing items), while being short enough that it's a nice brief bit of downtime between fights and exploring, instead of being a huge chore.

It's good! Again, I don't know how this one flew under my radar for so long! If you like the idea of a Zelda-adjacent sidescroller adventure, Phoenotopia: Awakening is better than any I've seen. Big recommend.

This game is nothing short of magical in my opinion, and it's a crying shame that it's flown so far under the radar.

Before I get into anything else, let me just say that I've completed this game 100% on multiple different platforms now, and I can say without hesitation that it's in my top 3 favorite games of all time. Here's my TL;DR- This is a Pseudo metroidvania, exploration, and puzzle game with unmatched atmosphere, solid gameplay, and solid combat. While the story is linear and it's not "technically" a metroidvania game, every ability you get unlocks a massive amount of new exploration, puzzles, and upgrades to find.

Atmosphere: Simply unmatched. The artwork is unique, vibrant, and super charming with each and every area being unique & distinct, accompanied by music that is downright mouthwatering, some of the best I've ever heard in a game. The world is huge, dense, and incredibly alive- there are hundreds of NPC's that populate the gorgeous locations and every single one of them has a minimum of two lines of dialogue that directly contribute to the world in some capacity, no throw away lines.

Story: Fantastic, but a little distracted. I love the concept and every aspect of it, but the main story (your entire village getting abducted by space pirates) is more-or-less ignored and instead you work to save the world from a separate force of hostile aliens. I think it works well, but it's a shame that this game wasn't popular and probably wont get a sequel following up on that 

Combat: Subjective. I loved it, but it does earn some criticism from most people and it's not undeserved. Unlike most 2d games, your character has momentum. You can't turn in the air, and once you've started moving in a direction it takes time to slow down and change directions. It lends meaning and weight to the movement system which I enjoy a lot, but others hate. What I do agree is kind of bad is that when you get hit there are no i-frames, and you REALLY bounce halfway across the room. Its very punishing for getting hit, although  the difficulty settings do let you adjust this combat quite a bit to make it much easier (which I recommend most people do). Overall, I think the combat is solid and people who nit-pick it are trying to work against is and play as though it's the same as other games when its not. You need to learn it and work with it before you see how well it actually works.

Exploration: Phenomenal. There are upgrades to be found in every single nook and cranny, and every single movement ability you get will unlock dozens upon dozens of new items to find. Some of these are VERY difficult to find, but if you like exploring I think it's more than worth your time.

Final verdict: One of the best games I've ever played. The amount of love the developers poured into this game is clear in every single scene and the experience absolutely reflects that. For me, this is a classic that I'll never forget.

130952142.review:
Phoenotopia: Awakening is a Zelda-like with engaging puzzles, interesting secrets, great music, and compelling atmosphere. 
While cartoonish and exaggerated in nature, the plot and characters are fun and charming.

The main focus of the game is exploration. The world is overflowing with a variety of secrets to find and puzzles to solve, with rewards ranging from money and common collectibles, to powerful unique items and interesting side quests. The most difficult puzzles (all optional) even required I use a pencil and paper to draw and write on. There is no quest log or waypoints, so figuring out side quests often is quite intrinsically rewarding, as you've got to figure it all out yourself. 

The main complaints I've heard about this game are:
1) The controls are janky/unintuitive because you can't turn in mid-air, sprint-jumps have a pre-determined arc, and you need to press the sprint button again after landing from a jump to continue a sprint.
2) Over-reliance on stamina; sprinting, rolling, nearly all of the key items, and all melee attacks use stamina. This, combined with (1), makes platforming and combat overly difficult.
3) There is no map screen while in dungeons, making them arduous and confusing.

Combat in Phoenotopia: Awakening is relatively slow compared to other contemporary 2D action platformers. Most enemy attacks are either slow moving, or come with both audio and visual tells well before the attack happens. This means that the impact that (1) and (2) have on combat is less than it may appear. You are "meant" to take to combat with caution and an analytical eye, making sure you make the correct movements at the right times. Of course, good reaction time is important, it is just not the end-all-be-all. As for the whole "being unable to turn in mid air" thing, the aerial melee attack is more of a high-risk, high-reward thing (it does relatively high damage). It is safer to stay on the ground and use ranged weapons to attack things in the air.

Even if you consider the combat overly difficult due to the controls, the game still can be accessible to you. Specifically, as I've already discussed, the main focus of the gameplay is on exploration. Similar to Super Metroid, (another came criticized for its janky controls), as long as you are regularly seeking upgrades, tanking your way through combat encounters is fairly viable. This becomes especially true if you stay prepared with healing food. While food takes time to eat, different foods take different amounts of time. Specifically, taking a dozen of food bits that heal only a little but are quick to eat can be quite easily used to heal in the middle of some of the hardest fights. 

The game also does not have much precision platforming, so the pre-determined arc of the sprint jump is not really that big of a deal. If you want more control, a regular jump will give you that.

As for (3), most dungeons in the game have quite simple layouts, with many unique-looking rooms. I can see why the lack of a map could be problematic for some, but I personally didn't have any issues with it. I actually found it kind of fun; the absence of a map screen means that the level design has to do all of the heavy lifting to be interesting, memorable, and navigable.

129707869.review:
Ok this game has a huge identity crisis. 

It's tagged as a metroidvania, but even if Phoenotopia was influenced by that genre, it's blatantly not true. The overworld, towns, NPC hints, linearity of dungeons, and scattering of optional areas to stumble upon in the map resemble Zelda 2. But more importantly is that at no point over my 6 hours played have I felt like my character has progressed in any meaningful way. There's a general sluggishness and clunkiness imparted into every aspect of the gameplay that comes from several weak designs colliding at once - the lethargic stamina bar is an obvious flaw, but that didn't stop people from loving Secret of Mana. 

Instead, every interaction of movement, platforming, resource management, and combat are at constant clash with each other. You move slow, but your enemies are fast and small; your attack has minuscule reach, deals even less damage, and is barely improved by the extremely sparse weapon upgrades; platforming and box-pushing are everywhere, but you never get a ledge grab, or double jump, or wall jump, or anything that would make navigating previous environments easier or more satisfying. You have no block, no dodge, no i-frames, and get thrown around by a number of enemy attacks, despite the abundance of combat. You don't get Link's directional aerial attacks (or variety of spells) from Zelda 2, nor the usefulness those abilities entail - instead your aerial attack and ranged items have uncomfortably delayed responses that share no rhyme or reason. Bosses present bizarre difficulty spikes where they spam arena-covering attacks, simultaneously encouraging heal-item spamming while punishing the default setting of having to eat mid-combat as if it's monster hunter.

Look I could keep going here, but I'll settle for saying that the "game" part just isn't fun. It's slow, tedious, limp, and stays that way - it's the first 30 minutes of every mediocre metroidvania when you have 0% percent of your arsenal, except that it never gets any better over the course of 6 hours. Maybe if the story was more engaging I'd be able to push myself further, but it's given me such a breezy and gossamer adventure so far that there just isn't enough in the plot or the characters to latch on to.

Phoenotopia: Awakening is a solid 9.9/10 for me.

There's a lot I enjoyed in this game. The story is engaging. The world is huge and packed full of interesting characters and rich lore. There are a ton of puzzles, minigames and side quests outside the main story. The constant sense of wonder and exploration is probably the strongest aspect of this game. Even though the rewards for exploring are usually just one of three types of collectibles, it's more about the journey than the destination. The feeling of accomplishment when you finally crack a puzzle or uncover a hidden secret is great and present throughout the entire game.

In terms of presentation, the art and animations are incredibly cute, both for the pixelated sprites and the backgrounds. Great use of color, too. The dialogue is charming and full of little jokes sprinkled in. Some NPC dialogues change after certain events, which is something that most players won't even notice, but it's a nice touch. 

The soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal. I love how some tracks have "calm" and "busy" arrangements that transition smoothly into each other as you enter or leave a fight. I also love how the in-world flute songs are tied to the soundtrack (e.g. the GEO song and the Royal Hymn) and how themes are revisited in different tracks (e.g. Moonlight Ravine, Boss Battle and Mother Computer all quote the main menu melody). None of this is groundbreaking or anything, it's just done really nicely. (As an aside, I love that the composer went with relative minor instead of parallel minor for the "sad" Panselo theme. OK I'll stop nerding out about the music now.) 

In terms of gameplay, I found it to be mostly smooth and satisfying. That said, I can see why most of the negative reviews focus on the controls. The sprint-jumping takes some time to get used to, and the tutorial for this mechanic is way too hard. The awkwardness of the controls becomes even more obvious during boss fights and the target shooting minigames. I played on PC and I found that aiming with the crossbow was nearly impossible without the mouse, which was weird and clunky for a game where I didn't need the mouse for the remaining 99% of the time. Then there was the "accidentally detonating a bomb I meant to throw" problem and the "accidentally throwing a box I meant to put down" problem. Maybe it's different on a controller, though. I know the game was originally designed for the Switch so maybe there is some unavoidable awkwardness when using a keyboard.

Despite all of that, the controls didn't really hurt my enjoyment of the game. If I had to point out a problem with this game, it would be those stupid sliding picture puzzles, and the one with the screens you have to turn on. I have no idea how you're supposed to arrive at the solution other than guessing correctly. Most of the puzzles in this game are really clever and involve solving a riddle or using your tools to overcome an environmental challenge, and then there's like two or three which are "hit the correct switches the correct amount of times". Thankfully, these are optional puzzles.

My other major complaint is that there REALLY needed to be savepoints in the middle of the [spoiler] Royal Archives [/spoiler] and after the [spoiler] Mother Computer [/spoiler] fight. The first isn't too bad because you can backtrack to the previous savepoint, even though that's still annoying to have to do. The second is atrocious design. If you want to [spoiler] beat Katash [/spoiler] and you die, you have to repeat that entire segment! That's three boss fights in a row! At least reopen the doors or something.

This game does get a lot of things right.

The music is very good. I usually turn that to zero or almost-zero in these games, but I left it on here (with a few exceptions, like the meeting the kids music that forces me to listen to that tune too long for their too-long conversation).

Being able to choose your difficulty and change it at any time is great. The game is very customisable in that way, but even the way the difficulties are presented to you are noticeably inefficient. First you are just given a choice of 5 star ratings for difficulty with no indication of what they mean. Then when you select one, the star menu disappears and you are given a character-by-character description of what your choice means for you, and you need to confirm it. You can cancel out of that if you like, and select a different difficulty and then read another character-by-character description. Why is it laid out this way instead of just giving you an instant description in the star menu as you hover the choices? I don't know, but this problem is a sign of things to come, as everything in the game seems to be set up with this mindset.

The combat is okay but generally below average. The melee combat, which you'll be using most of the time, is fairly straight forward and not super smooth. I was playing on the difficulty level that doesn't require energy most of the time (I tried it with energy being used at first, and that annoyed me a lot). The slingshot aiming is extremely weird - effectively like Yoshi's Island 2 aiming eggs, but the aim is slower and cannot be controlled in any way, and the shots you fire are slow and have a weird arc that I don't think the angry video game nerd would approve of.

The pacing sucks. This game has a lot of talking to NPCs and at first their conversations don't seem too long, but slightly more important NPCs have a lot more dialog and very little of that dialog is important. You start out just having to talk to your way around the opening town and it is very boring. I found my way out of that town by accident and I was grateful that I did. 

Then I had to learn some very complex moves very quickly, notably one that involved sprint-leaping repeatedly across 6 platforms, 2 or 3 of which were timed before they disappeared and I'd have to reset the puzzle. The problem here is sprint-leaping is not a matter of just holding sprint, there is a weird button combination of sprint-leap-land-sprint-leap-land that you have to do consecutively - but on short platforms, that is timed, at the beginning of the game. To begin with I thought this room was optional with some big gold at the top, but it is not optional. The buttons to perform all sorts of actions, not even complex ones are varied, odd choices. If I want to take a week-long break from the game, I will probably not remember how to pick up a box, and while I did place boxes down at my feet instead of throwing them a few times, I am still not sure how I did it.

The second biggest red flag for this negative review is a big one - there is no map. I got lost, and so will you, and no decent metroidvania should be without one. 

Ultimately though, there is one last flaw which is going to prevent me playing this game entirely - I cannot work out cooking. I tried cooking about 10 different things over 3 separate cooking sessions, and everything I try to cook turns to poisonous fertilizer because I failed to cook it. I tried googling to work out the cooking minigame but I can't tell what I'm doing wrong. And if I can't cook, I can barely heal, and healing in this game is already not easy as it is. Cooking appears to be all but required for any casual player.

I want to like this game, but the controls feel like they're designed for a completely different game than what you're actually playing.. Your movement when sprinting is unresponsive and your movement when not sprinting is slow, but the enemies all move and attack fast or have multiple projectiles (some of which detonate into further projectiles). You have a stamina bar that's spent on every action you perform other than walking, but you have no dodge or block and a very limited parry that only works on specific projectiles with no telegraph. Getting hit by almost any attack locks out your controls for at least half a second and can send you flying if the attack is arbitrarily forceful (as opposed to damaging) enough, but the conditions for triggering mercy invincibility are so asinine that it may as well not exist and the only way to recover from the flying animation is to have previous experience with either speedrunning or playing 2d fighting games competitively. You're expected to hit midair opponents in combat, but your ranged options glue you in place while aiming and the first of your ranged weapons uses a timing-based aiming system like it thought this was supposed to be a Paper Mario clone. You're expected to aim incredibly precisely out of combat, but the targeting reticule is glued to the end of an invisible selfie stick.

Special mention to the spear, which you can't even aim but are still expected to hit precisely with it during combat to have platforms to stand on, when it has a delay before you throw it. And if you're within what feels like the entire top third of your jump height it'll be too high for you to stand on it, and you're only allowed two spears at a time and can't just undo the new one without breaking both. Which is especially awful if you're in the middle of a long climb.

Then there are the straight up mean game design choices. Birds in the desert stealing your money in increments of 10 when there are multiple required purchases of over 100 currency; many NPCs with extremely specific multi-stage fetch quests, but no map or quest log; jumps across tiny platforms while being shot at, when any damage at all knocks you down and makes you start over; throwing 4 enemies with different attack patterns at you in a confined space so any attempt to avoid one attack sends you into 2 more, which stun you long enough to get hit by a follow-up from the one whose attack you dodged in the first place; an NPC in the third town who all the nearby NPCs [i]including himself[/i] imply is a scam artist, but actually sells possibly the single highest-impact upgrade in the game... You get the idea.

And if you're going to design a boss for an action game that has thus far been punishing enough to make the player want to bring as many healing items to boss fights as they can carry, what you should [b]not[/b] do is let the boss cancel attacks into a dash that, if it hits, locks out the player's controls for almost [b]10 seconds[/b] while he steals one of the player's healing items and uses it on himself while taunting nonstop.

The accessibility options barely help - you can skip the cast time on healing items and mitigate stamina management issues, but the available healing remains bound to your inventory size and you don't get any new means of avoiding or mitigating incoming damage.

I did mean it earlier when I said I want to like this game. The characters are charming, the art is gorgeous, the music is stellar, the writing is generally entertaining. But whenever you have to use both precision and speed at once, like during a fight or certain puzzles, all the fun gets sucked out of the game.

121831293.review:
Today I am going to tell you about Phoenotopia Awakening. I've beaten it twice, both times with 100% items, and one of them doing a 0% sub-4 hour speedrun before getting 100%. This is a game that is extremely good and not everyone is going to like.

It's a metroidvania. Any comparisons to Zelda 2 end at the overworld and random encounter design. The majority of the game is comprised of small areas (and large ones) that are broken up by the large map you move around in. From the very beginning, you are able to run around anywhere you can see and explore it. The sense of exploration in this game is pretty unparalleled. If you can think to go somewhere or try to reach a spot, even unconventionally, there's a high chance you can do it. The only guidance you are given is a general idea of where to go, and you need to talk to NPCs to learn more about each area. There's always someone to talk to who will tell you something to try. You just go do things, and there are a ton of things to do. Related to this: there is no map. This is something that may put people off, but the game is designed tightly. Each area you go to has clearly distinct rooms and doesn't suffer from the lack of map in any noticeable way. If you know where you want to be, you can get there. At most, you may want to note down places of interest to return to later. You explore in the overworld, find small areas to explore in 2D, and that's the formula.

The gameplay itself is solid. You can run, jump, crawl, roll, and hit things. Combat involves beating things up by spamming hits or playing it cool and going for aerial/charge attacks, which are more effective. People who run in and spam only light attacks are going to have a bad time. You can also prepare for exploration by cooking food (dropped by enemies or the environment) and buying better gear. Money is well-balanced; if you explore, you get enough money to afford things you want without much issue. If you don't, you're not going to have any. The exploration itself is usually finding a new place and doing puzzles in it, with combat generally scarce outside of overworld encounters. Most of your time is going to be spent looking for things and solving environmental puzzles that are almost all well-designed. Some answers are hidden in the background, some are logic puzzles, but there's always something to see. The pacing of major usable item upgrades is also done really well. You'll be getting a new tool to use in a pretty steady stream.

The music is extremely good. I don't know why the game has the right to have such good music, but it does. Some of it is stuff I don't care for, but even the tracks I don't like fit very well, with only one or two exceptions. And there's a lot of music. Tracks are generally not repeated and are unique to their area. I bought the soundtrack and kept about a fourth of the music in the game. This is unusual for me, and I almost never keep more than a few tracks out of an OST. The amount of variety in tracks is really bizarre in that I have no idea how the composer was good at creating such a wide spread of music.

For the graphics, they're pretty nice. Character sprites are more basic than they maybe need to be, but they're perfectly readable and well-animated. The environments all look good, as you should be able to see in the screenshots on the store page. This was originally a Flash game, which I did not play, but all of the graphics are retooled and clean. Visual information is clearly communicated to the player any time it needs to be. I don't have a lot to say about graphics—they're not that important. You can see them for yourself.

The story and writing itself: every NPC has something to say, and usually it's a joke that ranges from "okay" to "kind of funny", and that's totally fine. Some of them exist only to be jokes, and some will give you useful information while also being jokes. The presentation of dialogue is good, and there's none of that really obnoxious feeling you get from amateur writing. You know the type, where everything is trying super hard to be trendy and wacky. That doesn't happen here. The humor is enjoyable throughout. The plot beats themselves are actually good. Everything follows a natural progression, beginning with your entire village being abducted and going logically from there as you look for solutions. The scale of the story is a gradual build that's done very well, and while the actual events themselves are nothing incredibly special, it's nice to just have a game that's honest about what it wants to be and do. Phoenotopia doesn't try to be more than it is, and it drops many hints as to where it's going the entire time. It's the kind of narrative that begins small and grows bigger and bigger until it's encompassing some very large territory, but it plays it close to the chest the entire time without completely tripping over its own feet. It's something I wish more stories were capable of.

I can't really overstate how good this game is at letting the player do what they want. You want to go explore something? You can probably do that. You want to ignore the main story for a long time and sequence break to a new area you shouldn't be, detouring for 5-10 hours? You can do that. You want to just go fish for a while? You can do that. There are constant rewards for exploring. There are legitimately only two complaints I can leverage at this game, which are that some enemies can remove your hair dye for absolutely no reason other than causing annoyance (since you can reload the loss away anyway), and the speed of stamina regeneration would probably have been better served as a percentage than a flat value, as lategame stamina regen can take 10 seconds. There are ways around this, of course, but it's still a little excessive. That's it. Everything else I just really like a lot. I've played loads of metroidvanias, and this is up there with the best of them on the merit of its exploration prowess alone. There aren't many games that give you this kind of feeling.

If there was a netural rating, I would probably give this game that. I don't use positive rating values for games that are meh or just "not bad". People don't seek out games that are meh or not bad, they want games that are fantastic, games that are mediocre but get positive ratings dilute the ability to sort through what's great and what's not. In any case, my neutral / bad rating is based on a few of the game's, imho, biggest problems.

1. The first is the checkpoint system. When you die in the game, you can only return back to where you last saved, and if that save point is before a really annoying (though a game shouldn't have really annoying, challenging sure, but not really annoying -- there's a difference) point and you die and there was not a place you could save up to that point, guess what? Yup, you're doing that really annoying part again.

2. The first city you come across after the initial starting city is WAY WAY too big, it's overwhelming the number of people to talk to, the number of buildings you can go in, etc. This would be fine if each building and person had a purpose, but it's mostly just fluff. You're told to come to the city to find someone, so you wander the city for massive periods of time going in and out of each room and building trying to find the person, talking to each person, JUST to find this specific person you're supposed to talk to. It feels like such a damn chore and is torture. It wouldn't be so bad if the city itself wasn't so cluttered with background decoration and it was more obvious who to talk to and the other people and buildings had a purpose but for side-quest type of things. 2 b? . You spend so much time in the city mentioned in #2 that you get sick of hearing the same music and sick of seeing the same motif. Once you've managed to move the game forward a little you're still stuck in that same "theme". I think the title of this number could be called "Pacing is completely off". If that's not bad enough, just getting TO that second town feels like a real slog. 

3. The game is VERY grindy in terms of coins (called Rin in the game). Items, that are abilities, are locked behind purchases at vendors requiring lots of coins. Coins only drop from things like boxes being destroyed or chests. Even then, while the chests don't reappear after being destroyed, the boxes do but they then only drop a single coin.

4. The sprint mechanic. Wow is this bad. You hit shift and your character dashes forward. Continue holding down the direction and your character keeps moving, but jump and land and you go back to walking despite holding down shift still. You have to release shift, land, then hold down shift again. This is absolutely horrendous and becomes obvious how bad that is pretty early on in the game when you're introduced to the spring mechanic and have a timed zig-zag vertical jumping bit. Just imagine that. You hit shift and your character dashes and you can't jump without it toggling back off as soon as you land. This is absolute hell for a tight /small area to move in and a very small amount of time zig-zag obstacle course where you're switching directions multiple times. 

Overall, the game really just fell flat for me. The game just wasn't fun for me. I don't know what it was but it just wasn't "fun". The story was "meh", and trying to at least just get a good story out of the game, and forget about the game not being "fun", by moving the game forward was a chore due to the problems mentioned above. What story I could get was not nearly interesting enough to make me want to keep pushing through. (Though, why should any game make the player feel they are just "pushing through"?) I feel like the game was missing "something" but I can't figure out what specifically it was beyond just saying it wasn't "fun". I guess this is one of those times where someone would label a game as "uninspiring" and the problems mentioned above only detract from an already very mediocre experience.

I absolutely adore this game. I played the flash version so I was hyped when I heard about the remake. With that said, I can't recommend this game. It feels like the best worst game I've ever played. The Good (great, even)
-Sound and music. Whether lighthearted, cheery, wacky, intense, creepy, or somber, the music and sound fx do a great job setting the atmosphere.
-Visual design, both characters and the world. I'm a huge fan of the pixel art style. The enemy design is reminiscent of Cave Story, one of my favorite games.
-Cute characters with endearing and/or funny dialogue. The various antagonists don't do bad stuff just for kicks.

The Bad
-Clunky controls, making for awkward/frustrating combat and movement. You have to come to a full stop to charge your heavy attack or to make a ranged attack.
-Getting knocked around every time you stub your toe. Incredibly painful when trying to do platforming while turrets are shooting or enemies are jumping at you, and the aforementioned clunky controls mean you can't jump while shooting your crossbow or slingshot at enemies, compounding the issue.

[h1] Conclusion[/h1]
Phoenotopia: Awakening was a fun surprise for me, I started a short time ago, but I really liked what I've seen so far of this world that has a somewhat dark story at the beginning, but then brightens up in a fun and colorful world where we explore looking to bring back the normality of the village and home of our little but brave protagonist with pink hair, who despite her young age already knows how to defend herself from monsters, and loves stuffed ponies. ^^

I'll start by saying this is a game I really liked, and I can understand why some people might find it too annoying or difficult at the beginning (or during their whole playthrough). 

I didn't particularly enjoy the combat and the stamina system at the beginning. There're some difficulty settings to make it less annoying but I wanted to experience the game without them. I would also recommend the devs disable the "you might want to lower the difficulty" message post-death after a few times (or make it appear every X deaths), which was one of the reasons I could've seriously dropped it for (it took me a while to find there's a setting that turns it off forever).

Now, imo this game has something not many titles can claim: it has a certain charm of its own. Every character has a personality or quirk that sets them apart. The world might come up as "tiny" until you realize there're plenty of places to explore and things to do. Some of the side quests might have you helping a random character and later seeing little changes on some of the areas; or sometimes there's not a noticeable change in the world but they still feel meaningful. There's one particular cutscene on the desert town that is very endearing and I would've loved to see it again later. Thankfully, there's YouTube.

The music is top tier and I really like most of the soundtrack. The battle pieces are epic and don't get boring, the calm music is relaxing, and each place has its own thing. There're plenty of tracks I got to love, sometimes ending up staying in an area just to hear them for a bit. You later get an instrument which lets you play some of the pieces for different effects, much like Ocarina of Time.

There're also many puzzles, whether to traverse an area or to get an item. Some are clearly shown as puzzles (a specific type of dungeon), and others are not plain to the eyes. A few of them involve playing specific notes on the instrument, others require moving boxes, and some intended solutions might involve using the enemies. I might've done several of the puzzles in a non-intended way, oops.

While yes, sometimes the combat or the platforming were a bit too annoying, the bosses often have a special "thing" you can do which makes the fight less brute-forcey. I do suggest going for a max health / stamina run if you're going with the higher difficulty (a hard requirement for the hardest, optional boss), and trying to max out / get most of the equipment available.
The main weapon is a melee bat which takes a bit getting used to (not sure I got used to it tbh), and later you'll find some secondary weapons which you might find easier to use.


Overall, I think the game is really good once it gets going. There're plenty of places to explore, things to do, people to get to know. I found myself wanting to know what came "next", what was at the end of the dungeon, what else to learn about the world. I was surprised when I learned it didn't sell well, but I also happened to found it by accident. I hope this review helps bump it up and convinces more people to get lost in this wonderful world.

The game looks beautiful, and the music is good, but ultimately have some fatal flaws in the combat system that made it a very bad and frustrating experience, and is the main reason that I chose not to finish this game, despite really trying to look around these flaws. I'll start with the good:
- The pixel art is wonderful!
- The music is nice.
- The game has quite a few interesting mini-games and puzzles that I enjoyed.
- Has content that makes it more versatile, and not just all combat. 
- The story itself is not too bad, but the execution could have been better.
- The movement (walking / running) alone feels fluid.

The bad:
- The combat is sluggish, and your main weapon, a baseball bat, is borderline useless in many scenarios due to horrible range and a startup lag (especially when trying to use it in air) that really makes it hard to utilize for anything that is not just a sitting duck. You can charge it, but it will make you move in 1/4th of your walking speed, and the charge is gone if you try to jump. I really do like a challenge, but this game is challenging because your lack of control with your character, and not the enemies themselves. I really don't mind dying if I feel like I die because I am simply not skilled enough, but here I feel the frustration of dying due to a horrible combat experience. I ended up rarely using the bat in any combat where the enemies are in motion due to this problem, and in general I ended up just wanting to avoid any combat when possible.

- There is an energy gauge that is required for everything. When you run, or just do a basic attack, you use some of your energy. The artwork in the game also prominently features characters who all disappear at the beginning.

113176146.review:
Easily the best Metroidvania in 2021. Just finished it after 50+ hours and I have literally no idea on how could a gem like this fly under my radar for so long.

Think "Cave Story" with better story, better NPCs, more environmental variety, and Zelda-like items and puzzles. 

Positives:
-Great worldbuilding and lore.
I personally liked how it is exposed to the player: By exploring areas and interacting with NPCs outside the main story path. Collecting tidbits of info from conversations, journals and simple environment observation.
-Great sci-fi main story. Though it starts deceptibly cliched and simple. 
The town of the protagonist, a young girl named Gail, is attacked. And everyone in it is kidnapped. Only Gail and the kids of the local orphanage are left, since they were playing in a nearby forest when the deed happened. So she grabs her baseball bat and slingshot, and hurries to seek help at the nearest town. From that point things escalate, and in her search for the missing adults he starts to discover hidden and dark secrets about her civilization.
-Quirky, cartoony, and yet very well written NPCs.
-Rewarding exploration and sidequests.
-Very clever spatial reasoning puzzles.
-Awesome '16 bit' era music.
-Great stamina based combat system. Though it requires a bit of practice and is kinda hard to get initially.
Using the melee attack or any other combat equipment drains the stamina meter, which recovers over time. Initially only the short range melee attack is available, though the game introduces better and ranged combat items later on.
Enemies don't deal contact damage, so the short range is not really an issue. Also, jumping or moving has no stamina cost at all, the trick is knowing the attack patterns of each enemy, approach them with the best positioning and weapon, flail at them until the stamina runs out and 'dodge' their attacks by merely jumping or moving out of their attack hitboxes. 
You can also heal during combat by eating food, though it leaves Gail open to attacks for an instant, or a long while depending on the food.
- Minigames: There are several minigames and activities, such as fishing or cooking to prepare different healing and boosting consumables. The fishing minigame is specially fun and clever.

Negatives:
-Pixel art design is kinda hit and miss. Some enemies and environments are awesome, but for some reason the main character has an extremely simple design.
-No maps at all. Areas are easy enough to remember and navigate, but it still would have been a good feature to have.
-No journal to keep track of sidequests, good ol' paper and pencil are required. Not that bad, since they also help with the most complex puzzles.

Fair warning: The game is old school HARD. Though it has a great panel of accesibility options to enable/disable, so you can customize the experience to your liking. Eg: Greater stamina regen, no stamina cost for the regular attacks, auto-save, etc...

Seriously, if you enjoy story-oriented metroidvanias like Cave Story or Iconoclasts, then give this one a chance, it deserves way more recognition.

113102722.review:
I think this game is good, but not great. [strike]But as I'm a Negative Nelly, I ended up writing too much about my minor issues with the game.[/strike]

It's held back by a number of small issues that minorly inconvenience the player. Accessibility options can help with some of them, but not all (as someone who played without them, I suggest using them unless you're achievement hunting or always play on hard mode). I think the most annoying issue is the fast travel system, which is much slower than it needs to be and is locked behind optional collectibles that are also used for item upgrades. Another issue is there is no quick way to retry many challenges immediately; you have to see their dialogue from the beginning. These are different ways that the game makes it longer to traverse and backtrack with no extra challenge, and quite frankly it took me a while for the game to click for me. But once it did, I stopped caring about these issues, and just started enjoying myself.

The presentation is gorgeous. There are some legitimately amazing areas that I had to take in once I saw them, and I'm not the person to do that in games basically ever. The soundtrack compliments the graphics wonderfully. The load times are very fast, as one would expect from a pixel graphics title, but it's very welcome here. Dialogue from all of the NPCs is charming, and the world felt like a standout character. They really made me adore some of the sidequests in this game. There are some fun (mostly minor) sequence breaks that I was able to do, which makes me think this is probably a good speed game for anybody into that. There are goodies all over the place, so you'll find a bunch without having to go out of your way, but there are even more off the beaten path (sometimes even in places I thought the devs would have ignored!). The equipment you get is pretty cool; my favorites were the Bombs, Spear, and then the more late/endgame stuff. There are some really fantastic screens to complete, and there are some really awful ones (mostly optional at least). I loved it, and I hated it. But really, I liked it.

Story spoilers and thoughts on the ending that I'm still keeping really vague:

[spoiler]The narrative starts out very strong and sets you off into the world, where it mostly takes a back seat to the exploration or serves as a justification for going to some place you wanted to visit anyway, which I liked. So for most of the game, the narrative wasn't really a big deal to me. But quite frankly the ending is unsatisfying and a bit rushed. I didn't even realize I was at the final boss since it felt like there should have been more. As the exploration and world is ultimately much more important here, I don't think it's awful or anything but it is disappointing that it doesn't finish stronger.[/spoiler]

This game does a lot of things well but I felt like it was ultimately ruined by its poor combat and enemy design. It's not as difficult as games like Hollow Knight or Celeste but it is much, much more frustrating. Enemies feel like they were designed around a far more nimble and capable player character, and the Souls-style stamina system generally only forces you to waste time waiting around every so often rather than adding any real tactical tradeoffs. Certain critical combat abilities are hidden behind optional upgrades, which is great if you find them but makes the game even more frustrating if you don't. The difficulty/accessibility options make the game a little less tedious and frustrating in some aspects but they don't address the core problems with the design and controls.

That said, if you can tolerate frustrating combat and some general gameplay jankiness then there's a lot to like here. There's a huge world that is fun to explore, with lots of secrets to find. The various environments are visually distinct and look great. The character animations also look great. The soundtrack is very good. Towns are lively and full of NPCs that have more interesting dialogue than most games of this type. There's some Metroidvania-like ability progression, where tools from later in the game let you find new things in earlier areas. In general you can tell that the game had a lot of heart put into it.

104646332.review:
[h1] Delightful open-world metroidvania. The sheer amount of content, collectables, and stuff to do is outstanding. [/h1] 

[h2] Worldbuilding - 9/10 [/h2]
The post-apocalyptic medieval world feels enormous and lively, and actually is enormous. There must be hundreds and hundreds of NPCs across all the different towns and locales, each with their own story to listen to and often quests and tasks to help with. Although the game is focused on one "nation", you get the feel for a much larger world outside. Within the nation you explore so many diverse sub cultures and social groups that it's hard not to love everything about the world of Phoenotopia. The more "serious" questions about the past and the war that reset history are also slowly explored if you put in the effort to seek them out. The tone of the world is a bit lighthearted, and sometimes this is sharply at odds with some of the darker and more serious subject matter, but this isn't a catastrophic flaw.

[h2] Plot - 5/10[/h2]
The plot doesn't quite live up to the worldbuilding. When you look back at it from the end, the plot development is very simple and not particularly engaging. In particular, near the start of the game, you are given a task of "find what happened to your village", which isn't even addressed or developed until you beat a large 10 hour segment. After that point the pacing picks up, which is great, but there aren't really any narrative twists to add spice.

[h2] Combat - 7/10 [/h2]
The real-time platformer-style combat consists of selecting the appropriate weapon, dodging attacks and projectiles using jumps and rolls, and returning fire, all the while managing your stamina bar. Even more advanced techniques are unlocked later that provide a nice variety and power at the cost of difficulty. 

My only issue with the combat is the emphasis on knockback attacks. Many enemies can knock you a screen or two away, often into other enemies who do the same, putting you in a kind of stun lock. There is a technique you learn for avoiding these "tumbles" but it's really quite tricky to perform. In addition, being knocked so much [i] often [/i] results in you being knocked off-screen, which resets all the enemies' health and might as well be an instant death. If only there were a system to stop this.

[h2]Collectables - 9/10[/h2]
There are truly hundreds and hundreds of useful collectables in this game, ranging from stat powerups, to moonstones, to stashes of gold. The moonstones in particular have very intriguing and fun uses, and unlock items that really impact gameplay. Later in the game you unlock a hint system for finding collectables, which is really invaluable for completionists. I only wish the hint system included some extra collectables not in the "main three" such as [spoiler]lunar artifacts, skills, songs etc[/spoiler].

[h2]Music - 9/10[/h2]
Consistently amazing. In addition to the catchy themes you might expect, Phoenotopia has some creative ambient tracks that really innovate on what you expect say "beach music" and "farm music" to sound like. Even the music in the final area, which in this genre is traditionally dark, aggressive music is really fun [spoiler]80s synthpop[/spoiler].

[h2] Economy - 9/10 [/h2]
Phoenotopia has a fully-fledged enonomy, with buying and selling of items, money from quest rewards and chests, and a [i] ton [/i] of things to spend money on. I enjoy the "simplified" economy in this game where weapon and armour upgrades are all strict improvements on the previous level, so it's just a question of [i]when[/i] you unlock them, you don't need to optimize your build for different enemies. The same applies for the selling system - you always get the same amount for the same item, regardless of where you sell it (with a few minor exceptions), which helps to keep this simple and fun. 

[h2] Graphics - 7/10[/h2]
Cutesy pixel art. There are some phenomenal landscapes in the game: the Moonlight Ravine, and two certain underground lakes spring to mind. The cityscapes too are very detailed and engaging. But the characters themselves aren't particularly inspired. Even Gail, the protagonist, doesn't really have any iconic features.

[h2] Puzzles - 9/10 [/h2]
There are some really diverse and mindbending puzzles in this game. Given basic building blocks of "block pushing", "switch toggling", "music playing" etc emerge some really creative ideas. The sheer amount of puzzles in the game is unbelievable, including the main storyline and countless side quests. Even more impressive is that none of them seem repetitive, and every new area has a new type of puzzle for you to try. Phoenotopia uses the rule of 3 quite a lot, whereby it introduces a puzzle mechanic with one trivial puzzle, and then tests your understanding with two harder puzzles, and this consistently works well, allowing you to pace yourself. Particular note goes to the "GEO" puzzles, all of which pull this off perfectly.
