Disclaimer: I've played flash Phoenotopia and followed the game development for years so I might be a little bit biased/nostalgic. If you've ever played flashtopia before, get this asap, it's 10 times as polished while keeping roughly the same story.

Highly recommend for anyone interested a cute, relaxing metroidvania styled game. Lots of exploring pretty locations, lots of fighting and especially collecting items. The story is rather generic, you are a smalltown girl and have to save the world from unknown danger but it's delivered very well through the course of the game, constantly adding in new faces and background lore about the world as you progress. Ending could have had more work though.
The artstyle is stunning and one of the best I've seen in indie pixel games, Some areas really make your forget about the objective and just make you want to admire the view. The soundtrack just adds to this and comes with quite a number of tracks. I don't think I disliked a single track.

One thing I especially like is how many side areas and hidden places there are to explore. Entirely optional of course but usually they contain a hefty sum of cash or a boost to your stats and sometimes even interesting lore about the world. I also liked how your power level grows quite significally in some parts of the story, unlocking new and quicker ways to deal with enemies or to find hidden areas.

Some people say the movement and jumping is clunky but I didn't notice that at all in my playthrough, you get used to the controls pretty quickly. 
Some minor negatives I would say are some equipment items are pretty unnecessary and cycling through them can be a chore sometimes. Some boss fights are pretty tough and some puzzles could take some time to crack through (if you're really not interested in puzzles there's a community member who has made extensive guides about every puzzle and then some). There is also no map of any sort. Your memory will be your biggest friend here as there is a lot of backtracking. I actually kind of liked this, as I won't be constantly bringing up a map and can instead focus on memorizing this beautiful world.
None of these things affected me in a big way though so I wouldn't worry about those.

Now some things that might actually affect you: Farming money can be quite boring but it won't be needed if you explore for money and don't buy random junk. 
Some areas can be particularly annoying to traverse through *cough* Mul Caves *cough* White Towers *cough*, especially if you want to 100% them, but collecting enough stat-boosting items and food will mitigate annoyance levels to a degree.

Overall, Phoenotopia: Awakening definitely deserves more attention, a real indie gem to take your mind off the real world. Reason it hasn't been heard of that much is because of it's bad sponsorship/advertisement.

103257441.review:
Phoenotopia feels like an amazing classic SNES zelda/metroid/jrpg fusion with tons of content (30-40 hours or 50+ for completionists). There is a lot of combat, puzzles, exploration and plenty of backtracking to do when you obtain items or powerups that open up previous places that were once unreachable. I downloaded it because I had a craving to play another pixel rpg and I'm glad I decided on this one.

Story- Alright
Just like any other zelda-type game, the story isn't too deep. It's simple and it works, not much else to say about it. Conflict happens and your character's goal is to fix said conflict. It would be better to make more of the areas and bosses more involved with the main storyline though.

World Building&Characters- Top Tier
The world is fantastic, there's a ton of different areas that all have their unique theme as well as type of creatures and people who inhabit it. As for the characters, I usually can't be bothered to read filter text, but Phoenotopia had me reading BOTH lines of dialogue NPC tend to say, and not only because it was sometimes required for some secrets/quests. The writers went above and beyond in this game, and the humor hits where it is attempted. You wont be getting super close with side characters but you'll love them for the lines that they do have.

Combat- Decent with flaws
Combat is for the most part alright, but it also has most of the games actual flaws. It's typical 2d platformer combat, but where its different is usually for the worse. For starters, stamina is ridiculously bad in the beginning, and I advise anyone who is playing to absolutely go to difficulty settings and enable "stamina regens more quickly", and at least for the early bits also enable "normal attacks dont use stamina". No idea why some RPGs have you start out as someone weaker than the average human being, but until you get some energy powerups you're exhausted in less than 3 seconds and finding yourself able to do nothing but stare (or walking away). Secondly the knockback in this game is atrocious. There should be attacks that really make you fly back like getting hit by a boar charge, or an orc swinging a club, but you're playing as a human pinball and nearly every attack sends you flying. Thank the lord that they decided to make contact damage not a thing in this game, as it easily could have made all of this 100 times worse and maybe even irredeemable. Ranged attack weapons also really suck till upgraded, but I'm more of a fan of the bat so its not that bad to me.

Puzzles- Great
The puzzles in this game are what I wish more mainstream games could also learn from, but they're not mainstream because they require braincells so that wont really happen. Phoenotopia has you actually thinking in order to solve the puzzles blocking extra treasure, and even sometimes for the progression of the story. The main tool for this is usually the flute that is used sort of like the windwaker in LoZ:windwaker, except its not only for songs but also for inputting the codes that solving said puzzles give you in order to open pathways and loot.

Music- IBoughtTheSoundtrack/10
Music is a hard hit, and absolutely fitting to the area it plays for. Even areas I didn't like being in had some nice music to ease that pain. It has a whole lot of different ranges, going from classic 8 bit, to mellow piano, and even synth metal themes. I have some of them saved to my phone.

Controls- You might have to rebind
I started playing it with default keyboard controls. Don't do that. I later changed to custom keyboard+mouse, and then just used default controller. Aiming is really terrible with keyboard, great with the mouse, and pretty decent with an analog stick. One weird part of movement you'll have to get used to is that running has actual inertia. You will have to slow down before coming to a halt, skid if attempting to 180, and if you run jump, you're committed till you land, which is kind of odd because you have free movement in the air when normal jumping. There's also a lack of coyote jumping (being able to jump for a few frames after walking off a platform) so you're conditioned to jump a bit earlier till it isnt much of an issue anymore, but imo all platformers should have coyote jumping. The air attack has a long delay compared to the frame 1 bat swing on the ground, and outside being funny when Gail is stunned and rubbing her head after a headbutt, that attack is absolutely worthless and not worth picking up (you probably wont find it without a guide anyway). Lastly theres different jump heights you can attain from how long you hold down the jump button, but the smaller jumps are pretty strict on frames. Not SSBM short-hopping strict, but you'll get the wrong height jump quite often.

Comments
One of the biggest flaws to me and my 50 hour playthrough was that there is no option to respawn at the beginning of the room/boss room like other games have. Hell if there's a cutscene at the boss, you have to go through the respawning loadscreen, wake up from the bed at the save area, run to the boss, and then go through the dialogue again before your next try even starts. The biggest QoL would be to respawn at the boss room and have the dialogue skippable 2nd attempt and beyond, and I have no Idea how this didn't make it in to their accessibility patches. It would really get rid of a lot of the unnecessary frustration. Altogether the game is a gem, and I was really looking forward to the sequel, and was sad to see that it may be extremely delayed or even canceled due to lack of funding. This game deserves a lot more attention, and although it may have big flaws, it also has big strengths. 8.5/10, I hope to play Phoenotopia 2 one day.

Lineless pixels, colorful and varied aesthetics, smooth animations, it's a delight to look at and that alone makes exploring its many, many areas a delight. The sound design and soundtrack are great too, tons of memorable tunes and a huge variety of styles - maybe not an all-time great, but it was enjoyable start to finish. The game even does a solid job lore-wise; I admit I'd struggle to call the story itself great, especially with its bittersweet and inconclusive ending even in the best case, but the lore of the world and Gail herself does feel worth digging up, especially with how tucked away some of it feels, like you're uncovering secrets best kept buried.

And on that note, the gameplay. I'm going to avoid... The Topic™ for now but what this game excels at, it really excels at, and that is: EXPLORATION. This is -not- really a metroidvania in a typical sense - while it's a 2D sidescroller with combat, there are only a small handful of movement upgrades or tools that aid in exploration - most other things are more geared towards combat. But this game has so many diverse areas and so many secrets tucked away in its map, the vast majority of which feel perfectly fair and can be a DELIGHT to work out. Imagine it's late game, you're following a hint that the game's in-game hint system gives you pointing towards one of the last few collectibles you're scrapping out, and that hint leads to discovering an entire hidden area containing some of the hardest puzzles, platforming, and combat in the entire game, rewarding you with a huge lore dump -and- two upgrade items in one. I didn't even -like- that area but it's so cool that it's there! And there's just all sorts of things like that - environmental music puzzles, secrets hidden based on the sound of your footsteps, a map-spanning trading quest that leads to one of the best items in the game, and FISHING PUZZLES. The mad lad put FISHING PUZZLES in the game. On top of that there are so many optional challenges - races, box breaking minigames, target minigames, mazes, puzzle mazes, riddles, combat rooms, platforming gauntlets, often hidden in clever ways and often in completely optional but delightful to explore areas.

And every location has its own atmosphere - highly populated cities teeming with life, often containing a dozen or more internal quests, isolated but homely locations, secret dungeons, gloomy sewers, all in what ultimate is a fairly compact overworld that's so nicely connected via fast travel that it really only takes minutes to get anywhere, and despite lacking a map it's rare to get lost. And, again, in-game hint system that has such a miniscule fee it's basically free by the game's standards. In terms of sheer scope and density I could barely name a game that does both this well - Environmental Station Alpha is my measuring stick for density, and Hollow Knight for scope, and while this doesn't quite beat either in their own metrics, Genuinely the only games I can think of that outdo this game's sheer amount of content are the La-Mulana games, and I don't think -any- game could even attempt to best those. We're never getting another game like that again and that's fine. it does both so well the overall result is just as if not moreso impressive. 

it's a damn shame that the game plays like crap, then. Like, okay. The platforming is mooostly fine. You move at a decent speed and you have a run option, alongside some more platforming tools you acquire at around the halfway and three-quarters points of the game that fill out your repetoire and make Gail pretty athletic all things considered. But there's so many... nuances to the platforming that feel like they were put in place simply to make the game more demanding, not to make it play better. When you jump while running, you're committed to the arc - okay, I've seen that before in the aforementioned La-Mulana - but when you land, you have to re-press run? And if you land after a longer fall, you have to time a roll or get stuck in place for a second? Oh and you have to re-press run at the end of a roll or you get stuck in place for a second there instead? And a second time immediately after because you're stuck at normal walk speed? So let me get this straight, if I've performed a running jump and land from a high distance, I need to 1. time a roll, 2. time a roll cancel, 3. quickly tap run AGAIN, and if I fail any of these steps it breaks the flow of movement? ...why? Again, it feels like intentionally overcomplicating something that could easily be accomplished in a more simple matter - if it ended at step 1 I'd really have no problem - after the roll, I'm running again, a reward for timing that one button press correctly. The weirdest part is none of this is ever necessary? Every platforming challenge in the game can be accomplished without worrying about this. The hardest room I can think of, the Lunar Key room, is still lenient enough that you can take that moment of time loss every so often and still be fine - the real issue is that any mistake punishes you with like 50 points of damage for no real reason, but, whatever, there's a save spot literally one screen away, not a huge deal.

But then there's the combat, which has its own annoying nuances, and is THE part of the game that I hated interacting with almost every time I was forced to in any significant way. Gail is just not a good fighter. Her melee weapon is tiny, her ranged options are all very unwieldly - 360 degree aiming with a very short-range reticule never ever felt natural - and the air attack is the most pathetically slow move I've ever seen, you practically have to attack the moment your feet leave the ground to have a chance at landing a hit. So you've got a character who's already kinda sluggish unless you've mastered every aspect of the platforming engine, with slow, imprecise attacks. And damn near every boss requires such fast reactions and near perfect movement to dodge around, while often also being way more mobile than you could dream of being. And there's so, SO many enemies Gail is just not physically up to par with, either. I eventually just stopped using the bat outright and mostly fought with the crossbow and spear because, well, at least I can hit things without taking five billion damage in return that way, even if it's painfully slow and costs stamina.

And the unnecessary nuances come into play here, too - you get juggled like a ragdoll from basically any hit unless you can perfectly time a button press the second you land on the ground - and good luck reacting fast enough to taking that hit, because you fly fast! Oh by the way only one NPC in the entire game tells you this, in a weird spot, where you have to pay money to learn this technique. So it's just. Not tutorialized properly. So yeah, expect to get juggled, a lot.  The game tries to have a three-hit limit after which you stop taking damage, but it doesn't always kick into effect, and just makes Gail feel even worse of a fighter than the already low standards she sets the rest of the time. I basically ended up face-tanking my way  with food items through what I'm sure are very well designed bosses for a game where your main character is more mobile of a fighter than Gail - one boss I literally just stood in front of and wailed away at with my bat until I won and it was easier than trying to fight it seriously. Only the one superboss you need near 100% completion to even challenge is relatively immune from this and even then I'd bet you could facetank it with enough top-tier items too.

100160175.review:
This game is polarizing.

On the one hand, 'Phoenotopia: Awakening' has a lot of character. On your journey you will travel through a wide selection of incredibly vibrant and unique locations and areas, filled with lovable, funny and sometimes touching characters. The type of story it tells isn't anything new, but the execution makes it feel fresh. Writing, art, tech and music are all amazing at best and still good at worst, so there's a lot on offer here.

However...

This game is fundamentally flawed in terms of game design. Almost every element of the game's core design is busted in a way that makes the exploration/combat sections feel like a frustrating slog to get through. The only reason I (and many others) stuck with this game was because all the exceptional elements I mentioned before kept me pushing forward.

Combat is likely the worst offender. I'm completely baffled by the design decisions behind the combat system, which is completely directionless. Your character's attacks have little reach and you can quickly activate a run to speed up your movement. These mechanics are perfectly suited to a game with 'rush-down' combat, until you factor in other mechanics. You can't attack out of a sprint, instead you do a little roll (which doesn't give you invincibility). You can do a jump attack while running, but the jump attack has a ton of build-up (unlike the regular attack). Everything costs stamina, which recovers very slowly. At the start of the game this can be a major frustration as even the weakest enemy has to be approached with extreme caution to prevent you from running out of stamina and getting hit. And ooh boy, you're gonna get hit. lotsa enemies use charge attacks where they run straight at you at high speed (sometimes while off-screen). If you're charging a heavy attack or using any type of attack that has a build-up, your window to dodge is gonna be impossibly small. A lot of times getting hit feels really cheap, because you had so little time to respond. This is only worsened by the fact even the tiniest amount of damage will launch you backwards, often into another attack. You do seem to get some invincibility after getting hit, but not immediately, making it really easy to lose large amounts of health due to a single mistake. This is fine in a game like Spelunky, where its almost always completely your own fault you got hit, but here it feels mean. All this combines into an identity crisis personified as a combat system. Is it a high-action rush-down fighter? Is it a slow and methodical souls-like? Is it a wacky physics-based game? The answer is all the worst parts of the above.

I touched briefly on enemy design and this is a large part of the issue too. These enemies feel like they were designed for a different game and in general just serve as an annoyance rather than a challenge. Enemies don't have patterns to learn, each of them only has two attacks at most (save for the bosses). These attacks include the aforementioned off-screen hyperspeed charge attack, acid attacks that are fired in wide patterns and leave behind damaging pools that will prevent you from getting close to the enemy, enemies that explode when you hit them, enemies that explode when they hit you, enemies that pop out of the ground when you walk over it without any hint suggesting they're there and then explode, enemies that stun you for way longer than necessary leaving you open to even more attacks, enemies that actively move out of the way of the direction you're aiming and moving while shooting at you, enemies that will fire volleys of projectiles that can take out half your healthbar in one attack (thanks knockback!) and more! They can also knock you out of the room you're currently in, resetting your progress for that room. THIS ALSO APPLIES FOR AN OPTIONAL BOSS. If all that wasn't bad enough, these enemies are often packed close together or combined with platforming. Its not fun to have to tediously jump up a vertical shaft bit by bit only to get your progress reset when a single enemy projectile hits you.

Speaking of platforming vertical shafts, lets touch on level design. While the various towns you visit are full of character, the same can't be said for the dungeons/levels. Navigating these spaces can be difficult due to the lack of markers placed around the levels. I do my research so I know the dev mentioned he should've just put in a map and I have to disagree. The dungeons are largely a linear critical path with a couple of side branches for key items or collectibles. The lay-out isn't complex enough to warrant a map, it just needs clear pathing/player guidance. The issues with the combat and enemies are partially caused by the level design, too. For a game with such a restrictive stamina system you'd think there'd be a little more space between enemies so you have room to maneuver. This game doesn't agree with you, and insists that enemies be either closely packed together, be close to hazards so they can knock you into it, or be actively trying to stop you from completing what was already not a very fun platforming section. Platforming is generally okay as long as it doesn't involve climbing up vertical walls with a certain item (usually while getting shot at) or if its a timed affair like the parkour challenges. The same can't be said for the puzzles. I don't mind taking out a notepad and doing a Sudoku, quite enjoyed it in fact. But more often puzzles are either complete time-wasters where you have to slowly push several blocks into the correct position, or require perfect execution of several actions on a time limit (which is made very tedious due the movement systems).

You know what the worst part of all this is? Its so close to greatness, but these fundamental flaws tear what could have been a 9/10 game down to an incredibly frustrating 6/10. I think Quell (the game's creator) did a fantastic job in so many areas, but design is just not his strong suit. My love for the good parts lead me to investigate what went wrong and after reading his devblog I think I have a decent grasp on what went wrong;
Quell has a hard time looking at the game from an outside perspective. He's played the game so much that he isn't able to objectively look at its features anymore. To his credit he admits to this himself in his devlog. However, being able to do this is an incredibly important trait for a game designer. This wouldn't be as bad if he had a decent QA system but this was also one of his main problems (though I'm not entirely convinced he completely grasped the issue). He mentions the game receiving negative reviews because of its 'high difficulty', which was caused by him only letting a handful of speedrunners test the game. This could be interpreted as him being a little condescending, as the game isn't as much difficult as it is unfair. Lets not pretend people didn't like the game because they refused to gitgud, this isn't exactly Dark Souls. Things like the lack of player guidance, unfocused combat/movement systems and the reverse bell-curve difficulty (or unfairness) lead me to believe Quell lacks an understanding for the fundamentals of game design.
That's not to say I think he's a bad guy, or even untalented. In fact, I'm eager to see what he'll create next. I just really hope that he either reads up on game design theory or finds a competent game designer to help him out.

In the end, this is very negative review was not written out of hatred, but love. This game came so close to greatness only to have the experience be soured by such basic mistakes. I really hope Quell reads this and is able to learn from these mistakes  instead of feeling attacked, because that wasn't my intention. If he does, please get a designer to help you update this game. Don't leave it in this state, it doesn't deserve to be left like this.

PS. I know you're probably attached to the name but I think it might be holding your sales back.

100024960.review:
Phoenotopia is a bit of a mess, clearly not the work of developers experienced in making action platformers. The controls are a bit clunky, menus aren't super intuitive or convenient, aiming ranged weapons is a pain, the melee weapon is short, and the stamina system isn't integrated well enough into the game to really add much, though at least it doesn't get so much in the way that it drags everything down.

But, Phoenotopia is something I haven't seen in quite a while; the last two games I remember like it are CrossCode and Treasure Adventure Island. It's a game in which the developers' passion and vision drip off every screen of the game. The world feels alive with possibility, there's something for you to do or see around every corner, every NPC has something to say that someone enjoyed writing, every dungeon has little quirks and mysteries that make it feel rounded out and like more than just a series of tasks to perform. Bosses have gimmicks that make you use your head, and despite playing on the hardest difficulty I've only died once to each of them - once you understand the idea behind the boss the fight just kind of comes together as long as you execute correctly, and the game is fairly forgiving as long as you're going in the right direction.

The music is phenomenally good, perhaps not as ear-wormy as a Shovel Knight but a beautiful blend of ambiance and melody that reminds me of Valdis Story. The graphics are lovingly polished low-res pixel art in a style that's both cute and easy to read. The main character is animated with plenty of personality. Every part of the game feels like it had not just time and attention but real affection put into it, and it carries through to the experience. I'm not as far in the game as my hours (37 at time of review) indicate thanks to leaving it on while I sleep or go out to do things, but the time I've spent playing it has felt engaging in a way that only the best games from my youth did - not a time-devouring, hyperfocused way like a cyclical roguelike or a nail-biting way like a Yoko Taro game, but comfortable, happy, fun, like coming back to an old friend and just enjoying time together.

If you like pixel games, platformers with RPG and puzzle elements, Zelda games, or anything in that general style, give this game a try. It really wants you to enjoy it.

99964330.review:
A flawed gem if you like metroidvanias that focus on exploration.

The visuals and audio are fantastic, and it's fun to seek out secrets just to see what new areas they'll lead you to.
The story is ok but still compelling thanks to worldbuilding with a few fun twists, and there's a ton of NPCs with lore or amusing dialogue - your mileage may vary, though. Most NPCs are good-natured idiots and I found their banter entertaining, but it might be a lot of boring text for some folks (there's *a lot* of optional dialogue in this game). It's all very cheerful even when it's trying to be serious, which is kind of nice in the dark timeline we live in.

There's a ton of secrets and collectibles to find, and most of the puzzles hit that sweet spot where they're just difficult enough to leave you feeling like a doggone genius when you do solve them. I completed most of them without the wiki and I'm very not smrt (I especially liked the many song puzzles that require you to figure out a specific melody).
The game doesn't have a map which makes remembering some of the secret locations tricky, but there's a fair amount of side quests that'll have you traipsing all over and make you stumble back into whatever you forgot (and late game there's an NPC that can give you hints on whatever you missed). The world is also a lot bigger than I thought and unless you're dashing through everything, a first run will take a decent chunk of time (while I've been hunting for secrets somewhat thoroughly, getting to the end took about 25-30 hours).


Unfortunately the game has a major flaw and that's the combat.
It's not too bad for most of the game, but there are a few combat-heavy areas that are just frustrating to go through due to odd design decisions and controls that are nowhere as precise as the game expects them to be. The boss fights as well range from average to Frustrating® - as long as you're stocked up on items none of them are particularly hard, you just take damage in ways that often feel cheap.

There's many little quirks of control that add up to some frustrating fights. For example, you cannot turn your character in midair; you still have air control, but your character will only strike in the direction when you initiated the jump, which is frustrating when dealing with some of the fiddlier flying enemies.
Attack animations have a few frames of delay between the button press and the action, as well as some frames after, making quick reactions feel clunky and often resulting in taking hits.
Most enemy attacks (especially later in the game) will send your character flying, and while there is a 'recovery' move, the timing is finicky and you'll often end up bouncing around taking more damage before you even get to use it. You basically get a lot of stunlock damage chains like in Spelunky (less lethal here, but irritating).

This is all made worse by the Stamina bar, which takes forever to even begin refilling (2 whole seconds, which 
feels a lot longer than it sounds) and the recharge rate is so slow that you'll spend a not insignificant amount of time just pootling until it's recharged. The game has consumables to help with this, but it feels like a bandaid over a glaring design issue, especially since the stamina items are not that common and you have to go out of your way to get them.


So basically, if you're looking for tight combat, this is probably not the game for you.
It's not catastrophically bad and you get used to its quirks, but even then it never feels particularly good (it's a shame because you can see what they're aiming for but it's just not there).
I highly recommend enabling the 'difficulty' modifiers in the pause menu - I played most of the game without them, and rather than making the game easier, they resolve basic QoL issues. I really wish I'd played the game with them from the start - one of them speeds up the stamina recovery delay, which vastly improves the flow of the gameplay (especially since there is no ingame upgrade to this). The only one I'd leave off is  "allow instant eating of food" which kind of breaks what little combat balance there is (healing items are rated by how long they take to activate - like variable speed Estus Flasks).

And yet despite all that I still thoroughly enjoyed it and by the end I just wanted more to explore. I'll probably end up trying to 100% because the exploration and puzzles are so entertaining, and it's just got such a wonderful atmosphere to bask in.

This game isn't quite bad, I just don't think I'll ever bother to finish it. The art direction is fantastic, but it can't really cover for how iffy the game feels to play:

* The sprinting is just weird. It resets when you land (even if you're still holding down the sprint button). And pressing the sprint button causes you to start sprinting in whatever direction you're facing (even if you're not currently inputting any movement). In theory this could be useful, but in practice it just make the running feel really finicky. Sometimes you hit the sprint key too early and start sprinting in the wrong direction. Sometimes you're trying to run and jump between platforms, and you mistime repressing the sprint key so instead you do a non-running jump and fall short. I can't think of a single other platformer that does this, so I'm not really sure why they went with this weird sprinting mechanic.
* This game has Metroidvania-like backtracking but no dungeon map. So you'd better have a really good memory to keep track of all the places you can go back to!
* The range on "sword" attacks feels a little too short. This makes it hard to maintain any sort of "safe distance" when fighting. 98795583.review:
A hit-or-miss game that is both better and worse than it deserves.

The game is not quite a metroidvania, not quite a zelda-like, not quite a JRPG.

The exploration pattern is akin to a metroidvania, but the mobility upgrades aren't super revolutionary.

The level design is reminiscent of Zelda-style action adventures in the combination of puzzles and semi-involved combat. But there's no true Zelda-style dungeons to speak of.

It's got some JRPG vibes in how the story progresses through the world, but a lack of story-relevant bossfights and a comparatively low power gain throughout the game.

The game has a lot of charm and an engaging story. With well-executed but not supremely great pixel art and a good-to-great soundtrack.

The real tipping point is the combat and mobility. Both of which feel somewhat clunky, with more inertia to your movements than is common, and to a degree punishing knockback/ragdolling. Playing keyboard only didn't help my experience, though putting in more work on finding good keybinds for a Mouse & Keyboard setup might've helped the combat feel a lot more fluid.

Still, combat upgrades like weapons and skills are overall pretty low impact compared to health and stamina upgrades. Not that they aren't impactful, but to a large degree, it felt like stocking the right amounts of healing items and just gaining a larger health reserve did more for combat than half the available upgrades. The lack of core mobility upgrades throughout the game also didn't help.

The game has a lot of collectibles. More than warranted in my opinion, though a map and better mobility upgrades for backtracking would've done a lot to help as well.

The world/story and the combat/exploration is what the game is about, and how enjoyable you find them is gonna be what decides if the game is enjoyable overall.

In conclusion:

The setting and story are very unique and well-constructed. Truly the highlight of the game.

The graphics are pretty decent, though not overly spectacular. And the soundtrack is overall very good with some great pieces here and there.

The combat is kinda unique, a lot more measured than the norm, and if you don't master the controls it can feel more punishing and clunky than it maybe should, largely due to inertia and knockback-ragdolling.

The exploration and general gameplay is for the most part well-executed; there's a decent variety in kinds of puzzles and challenges, some of them felt really frustrating to me (in particular the ones involving enemy AI manipulation) and I expect someone else might be frustrated by something I enjoyed. The game is missing a map given the amount of backtracing for collectibles and secrets, and it's very light on mobility upgrades for it's format.

It also has a really chill yet engaging fishing minigame.

I absolutely adore Phoenotopia Awakening. I bought this game purely off of seeing it in my discovery queue and thinking the artstyle was really good and that it looked fun and I think buying it was one of the best decisions I have made in my entire history of gaming. Giving this a proper review is going to take a while so strap in, this is gonna be long.

[h1] Story [/h1]

The first thing to go over with this game is the story, and without giving you any spoilers, I think the story is really good. The initial driving force to set you out on your adventure of all of the adults in your hometown being abducted after having such an idyllic beginning really sets the tone well and motivates you on your quest. The story elevates and progresses really well over the adventure as you learn more about the world and the history behind it, with some new information as you progress being potentially shocking or awe inspiring compared to how the game's insanely cute art style sets your expectations.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

The gameplay I think is overall very good with a strong inspiration from games like Zelda 2 with how the world is structured into a top down overworld with side scrolling areas. The combat is definitely much better than that in Zelda 2, but definitely could be seen as mildly clunky with the delay on some attacks. I don't mind the slight delay at all, and combined with the stamina bar, it kind of reminds me of Dark Souls combat, as it shares these aspects. 
Puzzles are scattered everywhere throughout the world and there are some really clever ones that made me admire how cleverly they were put together, with maybe only one puzzle in the entire game I thought was too cryptic, and it was for optional stuff. Overall the gameplay is quite solid and I enjoyed myself throughout, but that's not the biggest selling point of this game.

Edit: I have read some other negative reviews of the game to see what people had problems with in this game to maybe give some extended information here, as most were linked to the  sprinting mechanics. The game does have a bit of a pressy feel with its sprint mechanics as landing from a sprint jump will cancel your previous sprint, and you need to hit the button again to keep running after landing. Some criticized this as being annoying, and the tutorial for this being a little too tight. I can agree with the second complaint, the room that taught this should have had a bit more room for error, but I didn't have an issue with the sprinting working like this. I got used to it pretty quickly and you don't get tested too harshly on it in required areas past the tutorial, which is admittedly strange. I'd recommend trying out the demo before diving straight into the game for this reason if this sounds like an issue.

Edit 2: I figured I should also comment about the game length as that can be an important detail for some people. Phoenotopia Awakening is a fairly long game with a lot of content, with my 100% playthrough clocking in at about 50 hours. I personally am fine with the length as I enjoyed basically my entire time with the game, but I know some may consider that too much of a time investment, and others may think it's good value for dollar to playtime ratio, I'll let you draw your own conclusions if you like as this is entirely subjective.

[h1] Presentation [/h1]

This is the biggest thing that has gotten me to hold this up as probably my new favourite game of all time. The presentation, being music and visuals, is absolutely phenomenal and had me loving exploring and finding new locations all the more than I already would have.
The pixel art in this game I think is probably my favourite I have ever seen with how well everything is stylized and how cute everything is made as a result. It took me about 5 minutes into playing the game before I was already gushing to friends about how the game looks, which is saying a lot considering I don't often get that way over graphics. From the bustling town of Daea to the incredibly relaxing Moonlight Ravine, this game gets atmosphere down so well that it joined the ranks of Okami and the Ori games to get me to genuinely tear up purely off of the atmosphere that the graphics and music provided.

Speaking of the music, this is one of the best soundtracks of all time to me. SillyTheWilly did a phenomenal job here and has made something I don't think I'll ever grow tired of. The boss theme is one of the best normal boss themes I've ever heard with me cranking the volume up super high whenever it started playing. 
Basically every area has a song that matches the location perfectly, with some as previously mentioned getting me to tear up. I've played many of the area themes as bgm for DND sessions as well and I've had some comments on how good the music was there too. Just overall a phenomenal soundtrack that deserves all the praise it gets and more.

[h1] Overall [/h1]

Phoenotopia Awakening is a true masterpiece in my opinion, and one of the most underrated games I've ever played by a massive margin. The fact that at the time of writing this there are under 1000 reviews is criminal as this deserves so much more recognition. Even before finishing the game with 100% completion today, I was already recommending many friends to check the game out, as well as gifting it to one of them, as I want as many people to experience this magical game as possible. I will absolutely replay this game in the future to likely get all of the achievements simply because of how much I appreciate it. I'm looking forward to any future endeavours of yours Cape Cosmic, you have a loyal fan right here.

[b] Masterpiece 11/10 [/b]

A masterpiece of a game.

I absolutely loved the puzzles in the game. A lot of them are physics based, timing based, and scattered all through out the world that it feels natural and immersive. Most of them are not too difficult, but they're hard enough to make you feel clever for solving them, either by deduction, skill, or being observant of the clues in the room. Hell they integrate puzzles in their world with the GEO club, which is a very fun idea.

The dialogue
I don't think I've consistently laughed at a game in a while, and this game's dialogue got me laughing throughout the whole adventure. It was probably one of the most charming things that kept me wanting to play more. Absolutely delighted when I got to a new area and have a new batch of NPCs I can talk to, and they can deliver some great one liners.

The music
Oh god is the music good. Sillythewilly did an awesome job, Stone Angel, Panselo, Caves of Mul, Moonlight Ravine, they are all peaceful melodic pieces I would listen outside the game. Some of the chiptune can be a bit annoying at first (like Thomas' theme) but it grows on you as you play the area. The battle music (especially the boss musics) perfectly captures the hectic feeling you get from fighting a new strong enemy, and made me feel hyped as hell to fight the bosses

The usability of your tight arsenal
Having no wall jumps, the spear is the main method for you to gain some verticality. I always like it whenever a weapon is also used for platforming, and the spear can also work as an explosive once you get the explosive upgrade. You can also use your bombs to use as a tiny platform, stacking two ticking bombs to gain some height, with a built in time limit before the bomb explodes. 

The aesthetic
While the pixel work itself seems to lack a bit of polish (for example the character sprites are a bit minimalsitic), the overall game aesthetic is very well designed. A lively desert city is adorned with decorations, colorful pots, carts, goods being sold, and colorful cloths hanged everywhere. They did an excellent job making a usually monotonous brown desert city stage looking colorful and pleasant to look at. A worn down abandoned bridge has tasteful debris scattered everywhere, walls crumbling, old statues falling apart, old mossy crates you can smash to get a few pennies. They create a very believable and natural amount of clutter to make the area look nice and realistic, like what'd you expect from say a club house, a laboratory, or a beautiful ravine

The cuteness
The game overall is very cute. From the frog, bee and slime enemies, characters like Fran, and of course the actions you can do. Crawling gives you a cute pacing sound, and if you bonk your head with a headbutt attack your character will rub her head in pain. And if you failed at cooking, it will blow up in your face.

Other positive qualities I could think of
-the touching aspects of the story (where Gail first came from, or when you find the young king's deceased parent's gift for him)
-the accessibility options (because using stamina on normal attacks seem annoying as hell. I prefer eating in real time as it adds more challenge though. A lot of people had complained about the difficulty, and the devs themselves had admitted that they did an error on playtesting, by recruiting highly skilled playtesters (think Smash tourney regulars, and hardcore Dark Souls fans), but with the help of the accessibility options, you can smoothen the experience.

What I didn't like much about the game
-the later parts of the game 
My favorite aspects of the game, the funny dialogue and the colorful settings, decreased in the later parts of the game. These areas are:

the Last Wall 
a wasteland of a once prosperous city, littered with ghoulish robots of ancient technology. While scary, fitting, and a good testament of the player's skill, I missed the more colorful areas while I was playing it. And zero funny dialogue in that area.

E.D.E.N.
a cold and heavily guarded laboratory. A difficult area of the game (which makes sense because it's the final area). But once again I miss the more colorful and cheerful areas. But at least there are some funny dialogues in the old entry logs. 

Between those two areas there are the Mul Caves and Aurantia however, two more colorful and lighthearted areas, so not all of the late game areas are like that.

Overall I highly recommend this game. It is a very underrated gem, a very nice experience and my favorite game I played in 2021 so far.

97122926.review:
To put it bluntly, I'm not the type of gamer who has much affinity for releases that make frustration a calling card; with a backlog like mine spending considerable time bashing my head against a digital wall just doesn't hold much appeal. So here I am, writing about a game that made me curse at my screen more than any other I can immediately recall...which, not only did I finish, but logged 70-plus hours on the game's clock and racked up a 97 percent completion rate to boot. Moreover, afterwards I immediately searched out and played through the original Flash-based Phoenotopia, just to get a better sense of where Awakening came from...oh, and also double-dipped when a DRM-free version came out.

So yeah, whatever misgivings I might have about Phoenotopia Awakening there's something truly special happening here, and I'll do my best, hopefully without spoiling too much, to explain what it is.

You take on the role of a young woman who's spent her entire life in a small town, but abruptly finds herself obliged to set off into the wider world and piece together its mysteries; let me tell you, this game makes darn sure that the player feels just as overwhelmed as she does. Outside of the general direction you need to take to progress the story you are granted precious little guidance, not only in terms of where stuff is but how any of it works; there's plenty of space to cover and lots of things to mess with, but you can forget any sort of map, quest log or other such reference to help you keep track of it all, unless you doodle it up on an IRL piece of paper yourself. To figure out which way is up you're expected to constantly and consistently explore, experiment and extract every bit of incidental information you encounter as you wander, and this takes a LOT of time and effort.

This sense of slow, gradual struggle extends - and how - to the game's combat; while moving about and attacking generally feel solid enough, an ever-looming stamina meter limits how much time you can spend on the offensive, and your range and speed seem almost constantly outclassed by your adversaries, who will ruthlessly ambush you, snipe you, gang up on you and chase you down from the word "go". If that wasn't enough, you'll frequently find yourself not only knocked back upon taking a hit but careening helplessly between nearby hazards, damage piling up all the while, before a bit of mercy invincibility finally kicks in to give you a fleeting moment to regain your footing...or, just as likely, mess up your counter-attack timing, eat another haymaker and start the dreadful sequence all over again.

In so many words, there are times where this game will make you want to yank your hair out; I couldn't begin to list the times other titles got me half as hot under the collar as this one did and wound up swiftly ejected from the disc tray, never to enter it again. But this time around, surprising even myself, I didn't quit and move on to something else; I kept going. Kept dying, and retrying, until I could finally progress. Why?

Because I don't think I've ever played a game where being able to keep going was just so [i]worth it.[/i]

Simply put, if you're the sort of gamer whose favorite part of a given playthrough is the "I'll ignore the storyline and just meander around for a while" part, you're in for a rare treat; as much of a struggle as it can be to make your way in Phoenotopia's world, every last tidbit you do manage to get your mitts on is uncannily satisfying to obtain and renders you even more curious to dig further, no matter what. This extends not only to the platforming and puzzles, but even the often-brutal battles: as elusive as such mastery is, few pleasures can compare to FINALLY learning to spot a once-inscrutable enemy hiding in wait for you, charging up a full-power attack as you approach and sending the cheeky bugger flying across the screen with a perfectly-timed, wonderfully visceral [b]*THWACK*[/b].

While this manner of experience is admittedly subjective in nature, looking back on it now I still can't help but marvel at how natural, how giddily organic it felt to open the world up, bit by bit; nearly every time I'd pass through a previous area I'd find myself, at least once, suddenly thinking [i]"waaait a sec, maybe if I..."[/i] and it's rather amazing to recall how frequently and endearingly my curiosity and persistence was rewarded. Moreover, despite its considerable length the game very seldom feels like it's padding things out; every new place you travel to has fresh sights, sounds, threats and treasures to experience, and the thrill of discovery never truly fades. To wit, even during my very last play session with the game, before I headed to the final boss I took an "eh, why not" detour to a particular puzzle that had stumped me for several dozen hours prior; sure enough, I noticed something I'd missed before, gave it another shot and at long last managed to check it off the list.

Out on the periphery the grueling portions of the journey are further softened by Phoenotopia's uniquely inviting vibe; while many games of this ilk tend to revel in their cruelty, constructing worlds full to bursting with oppressive and foreboding atmosphere, the developer here chose to buck the trend and keep the overall mood light, humorous and cartoonishly charming. Darker undertones certainly do exist, especially if you peer into enough distant corners, but you're far more likely to remember, and be urged onward by, the game's incorrigibly quirky bit players, from important secondary cast members to the countless nameless townies you'll chat up, and the array of silly antics they present for your amusement.

Said characters, and the world they inhabit, are for their part rendered in a somewhat "blobby" pixel art style, which limits the amount of inherent detail present in any particular sprite or setting (and can occasionally make background and foreground elements difficult to parse), but also lends the visuals a strikingly "gentle" air, never failing to look anything less than pleasant, and frequently quite pretty. The accompanying soundtrack reflects the game's eclectic roster of influences (note that the game is not a "pure" Metroidvania, though I'll leave it to you to experience just how), featuring everything from peppy chiptunes to somber piano melodies to minimalistic ambience to a boss theme that wouldn't be terribly out of place in a Ys title.

As grand of a time as I had with this game, I must acknowledge in the end that my memory of it is a bit tarnished by my judgment that it does cross the line one too many times from "sticking to its vision" into "refusing to get out of its own way". If you prefer games that "get to the point" this one is obviously not what you're looking for; Phoenotopia Awakening is best experienced by going in as blind as possible, prepared to very slowly immerse yourself in everything it has to offer and re-approach things from several different angles when you find yourself either stumped or unceremoniously smacked to the Game Over screen. If this setup sounds even somewhat appealing to you, do not hesitate: Cape Cosmic has ABSOLUTELY earned Phoenotopia Awakening's full asking price.

In a nutshell: [i]It's Got What Humans Crave.[/i]

More than worth your time and money if you like exploration-heavy action platformers. You could call it a metroidvania as it has progression based on items/abilities that give you access to new places, but that would be somewhat misleading because it doesn't have a map. 
Rather it has numerous smaller areas of all sizes connected by an overworld. In this way it's directly inspired by Zelda 2: Adventure of Link. The inclusion of a flute you use to play songs for various purposes is another obvious Zelda influence, and should be appealing to fans of those games. 
Some of the dungeons are conventionally designed, requiring navigation like the dungeons in Zelda 2 or normal metroidvania maps, while others work a little differently. There's a great variety in the environments and puzzles.

I've backtracked quite a lot, talked to every NPC, and found all kinds of stuff, but there are still a handful of important sidequests that are leaving me absolutely stumped. Maybe this is a good thing to you, maybe not, but it will scratch that itch for finding secrets on top of having an above average amount of content.

The setting and story is very interesting, and relatively rare in gaming. If you think it looks generic, or childish, don't be fooled. It gets crazier the further you go. 

It has to be said that the music is outstanding.

93774604.review:
Phoenotopia Awakening ultimately is a charming game that suffers from some very serious problems relating to the combat and antagonist. Its worth your time, but it isn't for everyone.

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

[b] Worldbuilding: [/b]
The world and characters for this game are just charming. There isn't much more to say, I enjoyed the one-off villains, the Supporting characters are likable, and the questlines are interesting and unique. Atmosphere is certainly down with the towns and Dungeons. However, there are a lot of filler characters. I honestly could not tell you the names of most of the Bandit leaders, other than the one you go to in order to get some upgrades, despite them all having distinct personalities and appearances. 
 
[b] Exploration: [/b]
The best parts of the game is definitely exploring new areas, Gaining access to more and more of the area as you solve puzzles and talk to characters. Its just a treat to put the pieces together, and while it is annoying on a second playthrough to have to retrace your steps exactly, the first playthrough is wonderful. It also ties into the worldbuilding, as the two go hand in hand. 

[h1] Cons: [/h1]

[b] Stamina: [/b]
The combat is less than desirable. Its not bad, but its not good. By the end of the game you can demolish any enemy with the right upgrades, so combat isn't necessarily difficult if you know where to look for upgrades (With the exception of the Secret boss, which you need all health and stamina upgrades to fight, and is great). The problem is just that the Stamina mechanic is poorly implemented. Alternate weapons (Which are your main damage dealers against endgame bosses) devour stamina like there is no tomorrow, and it takes an eternity to come back, and using anything during the recharge causes it to stop, and since there is a delay between using a weapon and stamina coming back. Stamina recharges at the exact same rate at the end of the game, as it does at the beginning. This leads to a lot of waiting, unless you constantly stock up on an item that drastically speeds up stamina regeneration for 2 minutes. Its not hard, its just annoying 

[b] Difficulty curve: [/b]
As I've said earlier, the game isn't very hard towards the end, when you have all the games collectables at your disposal. The hardest bosses (Excluding the Endgame Superboss which is intentional) for me weren't the last ones, but instead the 3rd (Great Sand drake) and 5th (Katash). Because these were both punishing bosses situated a long way from towns, meaning that upgrades weren't readily available, so I just had to ram my head against them until I got good enough to beat them at my current power level. I played the entire game without any of the Combat modifiers that are supposed to make the game easier, and the difficulty felt spikey. The 1st, 2nd, 4th, and everything past the 6th just felt easy (Once again excluding the endgame superboss). 

[b] Antagonists(SPOILERS): [/b]
My only real complaint with the main story is its lack of a substantial main antagonist. The closest thing the game has is Katash, the leader of the Alien forces searching for the same weapon that the player. And he shows up twice (3 times if you count a brief appearance of his shadow through a window), one for each of his boss fights. And even he is subservient to an Unseen "Master" who is hinted through statues and lore text to be the main villain, but is never seen. So the Villains fall into the category of "Vaguely threatening presence that vaguely does bad things"

TL;DR: Good story, but lacks a strong antagonist. Combat has a poorly implemented stamina mechanic and difficulty is spikey. Overall, Make sure to search the overworld and towns for upgrades before you go to any dungeon, and don't be afraid to use the accessibility options. Don't play it for the combat, play it for the exploration and characters.

Well, I just closed the game because I lost 50 min of progress because there are almost no save points in the castle. Don't mind me, I can recover my progress later. I lost 50 minutes of playtime, I can use a bit more of my time to give some feedback. Hope the developer reads this and get a better understanding of why the combat mechanics made people (me included) so upset.

It is a nice game storywise, has a lot of mechanics for crafting/cooking which normally aren't explored by most platformers. There is no map for tracking your current position in an area, but it doesn't affect gameplay that much. Puzzle solving is a plus. No option for petting sheeps and chickens.

The main problem of the game is the combat mechanic (there are also fewer save points than necessary in the castle, but lets talk about what bothered me the most - I think that for the advancing of this story, combat shouldn't even exist). 

You can check on most negative reviews that the game is kind of unforgiving. Well, I play tons of metroidvania games, and what bothered me the most on this game is how different (in a bad way) the character respond from a tipical metroidvania character. There is no problem in utilizing the mechanics that are nicely done on other games, right? No reason to reinvent the wheel, and to fail in the process.

You have either a short range melee attack or a ranged attack that requires precisely timed shots (which can be deflected by enemy fire). That includes the following projectiles: stones, javelins or bombs. Short range for melee attack is lame when you have no dodge mechanic, and not all enemies get stunned when attacked.

When you get hit, you have no invulnerability frames. That means you can be hit multiple times until you react the ground for Ukemi. I am ok with being knocked back (hello curse of the moon), but being on a receiving end of a combo is not ok. 2D platformers REQUIRE invulnerability frames after being hit. Even Cuphead (which is known for being unforgiving) has it.

Maybe I didn't pay enough attention to tutorial and stuff, but the command normal down+L2 was never presented to me, and it helped quite a lot to dodge (USE RIGHT AT THE LAST MOMENT POSSIBLE TO PREVENT ENEMY AUTOCORRECT). It could be binded on R2 instead of a command normal though, I am currently using R2 only for teabagging.

Once midair, you can't change the direction the character is facing. Therefore, if you need to intercept any projectile or hit an enemy, you have to wait until you reach the ground.

Enemies have auto correction on their attacks. If they are charging an attack and you go to their back, they follow you instantly (why is it charged if the enemy can change its direction midway?). Projectiles throw by enemies also ignore platforms (but not boxes).

The basic air melee attack has longer starter time that the ground melee attack (which most metroidvania games doesn't have - this is the reason why jumping and attack midair feels much more confortable than ground ones on games like Momodora, Hollow Knight or Bloodstained). There are some bosses that require the player to hit an basic air melee attack, and the feeling of having a higher startup on the air is awful. The air attack is just too slow to work.

It also seems that grinding is required if you want to get better armour and weapon. The gold you earn following the main quest isn't near enough to get your upgrades.

I am still playing the game, this list might increase.

I have no hope the developers will ever fix these issues, but if they do, I will be more than obliged to recommend this game.

Edit: I've completed the game after 28h for 32% game completion. Most of the money I got in the game was spent on food in order to survive the bosses, since in some cases it is better to just facetank everything to rush the boss ASAP. No reason for learning the boss mechanics, because there is none.

On the highest difficulty the fights that are intended to be hard generally demand one or two retries but never pose a brick wall (at least for me, though I consider myself a good player). The only exception was one boss who took me around ten tries. But if you are having trouble, there's a variety of options you can toggle to make the combat easier; the difficulty selection at the beginning just picks from a few default configurations (with the "max difficulty" just turning them all off). Some of the optional side content is much harder though.

There's a variety of side content and minigames, of varying scope. Pretty much all of them are fun, well designed, have appropriate length and reinforce the tone and style that the game was going for. The same can be said for the levels.

The story is fun and endearing, albeit not award-worthy. Visuals, music, and dialog are all pretty great. Expect a childish tone of adventure despite the high stakes (except in a few specific areas where they intentionally invoke a much darker atmosphere).

In terms of length, it took me ~35 hour to beat on my first playthrough with 50% item completion. There's two full hidden levels which add a few more hours onto that, and a huge number of smaller side areas/puzzles/quests/secrets which will extend it much further if you're a completionist (even a few optional bosses). Fortunately if you are hunting for 100% there's an NPC who gives hints to stuff you haven't found yet. Also there's 2 challenge achievements which require a full second/third playthrough.

Overall, this is a title that shouldn't be missed by Metroidvania lovers.

91589698.review:
Phoenotopia: Awakening is a demanding game. It demands that you fight smart. It demands that you pay attention. And it demands that you pursue optional content, if you want to keep up with its power curve. But if those demands don't turn you away, then you should absolutely play it - it really is something special.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Phoenotopia's most-criticized element, by far, is its combat. It's definitely unforgiving, and it punishes reckless aggression with brutal knockback chains. However, it also gives you some interesting tools: light/heavy/aerial melee attacks, a number of ranged weapons for different situations, and some incredibly useful consumables (STAMINA REGEN). The end result is surprisingly strategic - figuring out [i]how[/i] to attack is often more important than skillful execution. One last thing to note: completing side content (collecting life gems, finding Ouroboros Scrolls, etc.) will make you much stronger, and thus, make the difficulty more manageable. So do that!

Outside of combat, Phoenotopia has a lot to offer. Exploration, light platforming, item-hunting, puzzle solving...and the puzzles, in particular, are great. They're demanding, like everything else - you have to write stuff down, figure out patterns, pay attention to background details. But they're incredibly satisfying to figure out, and I didn't find any of them to be frustrating or overly cryptic.

[h1]Story[/h1]

On the one hand, the game's central plot is a little messy. It awkwardly shifts focus at its midpoint, leaves some serious loose ends on the table, and ends kind of abruptly. But Phoenotopia isn't really [i]about[/i] that central plot. It's more about exploring the smaller stories of each area (which are consistently great); about interacting with fun, well-written characters; and about discovering more of the world's secrets. The payoff on those fronts is much better - so ultimately, I walked away satisfied.

Also, despite the weaknesses of the central narrative, the game has very solid pacing, with some moments of great tension and some long, well-earned breathers. If this element was weaker, the game's back-and-forth transitions between cheerful fantasy and ominous sci-fi would feel abrupt. But instead, they work very well, and the game never exhausts you with too much of the latter.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]

The sprite art is great, especially in motion, and the backgrounds are gorgeous. The music is also lovely: it nails the adventurous mood of a desert town, the serene beauty of a far-flung beach, and the looming danger of an ancient lab. Combined, the effect is enchanting, bringing out the same sense of wonder that the best Zelda games do. I have just one small criticism of the game's art direction: sometimes, I can't tell what's part of the background and what's not. Luckily, this problem is mostly confined to non-combat areas, so it's not a huge deal.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Did you know this is actually a remake of a 2014 Flash game? I played that game back in the day, and I thought it was a flawed gem. But Phoenotopia: Awakening fixes every problem I had with the original, while expanding on everything that made it good. It's everything a remake should be, and it's well-deserving of your time.

I really wanted to like this game. I love the premise, I love the genre, it sounds great and it looks pretty. The level design further reinforces this trend of making things as slow as possible. The levels in this game don't really wrap back in on themselves. There are a few shortcuts here and there, but by and large you go through the area to the end, then it warps you back to town. That's great, but it's not there when you backtrack for items, so you end up just walking back and forth through the entire area.

This is holds true even when it doesn't make logical sense, like at the top of the windmill towers. Despite it regularly allowing you to fall from one screen to another, if you try to jump off the top it just gives you a bit of damage and puts you back up there. I either have to move jump or accept to something else. Both go against decades of precedent and just feel super awkward.

Aside from that, movement feels stiff and clunky. When you dash jump you're on a fixed trajectory, so it's easy to misjudge your distance and have to repeat jumps or entire sections if you fall. There's a core of a good game here, but some questionable design decisions and some very rough edges just keep it from realizing that potential.

89922102.review:
Methinks this game is underplayed!  I was checking up on possible upcoming game updates and I read Phoenotopia's developer blog.  It seems that there won't likely be any further major developments or sequels, primarily because there haven't been enough sales to do much beyond keep the lights on over there.  Well, this is a travesty...I say TRAVESTY, sir/ma'am/mx!  So here I am, come to extol the virtues of this game and hopefully help to better reward its creators for their endeavor!

!WARNING!  Very minor spoilers...teeny tiny, really...hardly worth mentioning.

VISUALS: Charming, gorgeous art style.  Its quite colorful, so if you demand moody, limited color palettes and pixel art that is super abstract or realistic, this might not be for you.  This is pretty cartoon/anime, but I think it's well done, especially considering how far it's come from its earlier iteration.  And yeah, it's super cute.  Get over it.  Don't be that machismo that don't do 'cute'.  Make room for a wee bit of cute in your digital diet.

MUSIC:  Solid, catchy, front-and-center, energetic melodies.  I mean, part of the game's mechanics kind of rely on memorable melodies, so you will likely be occasionally humming these as you go about your day after a play session.  There are also a few pieces that go a long way to provide great ambiance as well.  I really appreciated the mysterious and somber, even lamentable tones lent to the early game temple, especially once I leaned a little bit about its former occupants.  It really is rare when a piece of music makes you stop moving and ponder the fate of a people.  My only gripe is I that I found myself yearning for a bit more subtle and subdued ambient stuff to counterbalance the bright and bouncy stuff.

COMBAT:  Controversial, considering some other folks' appraisal of the system, but I like it and I have it on hard mode.  Mind you, you have to practice (God forbid) to get super accurate and efficient with combat and not get your apples handed to you, but I enjoyed the challenge of this particular blend of combat mechanics.  I also liked that so many weapons have a useful utilitarian purpose essential to the game's platforming element (more on that later).  Combat progression is simple and coincides well with story progression.  You can put a little extra time and effort gearing up to get ahead of the curve if you like, or you can often wade in with sub-optimal gear and still survive if you are patient and skillful enough.  The movement mechanics feel good and the things like dash, roll and special attacks flesh things out.  Energy management is critical, which may annoy some, but to me it just serves as an incentive to explore and grab energy upgrades.

STORY:  I have yet to finish the game completely, but I am nearing the end and I've liked it so far.  One thing I am a sucker for is a world littered with remnants of fallen civilizations.  If you like that sort of thing, this game should scratch that itch.  I usually dislike the cool-trumps-logic medieval fantasy/sci-fi tech mashups (looking at you, Final Sci-Fantasy), but in my opinion, Phoenotopia makes it quite palatable and gives you a decent logical reason for the coexistence of the two elements. I also think the game strikes a good balance between making the protagonist important, but also sharing the spotlight with other key players and even the people she knows and cares about that can't come on the adventure with her.  I find myself caring about the concerns and fates of various NPC's.  As for the dialogue, it definitely slants toward lighthearted humor, but it does a fine job of it.   Almost everyone has some witty or silly thing to say as a reward for talking to them and those beady eyes everyone has just make it all the more humorous to me.  Plenty of folks drop snippets of history and lore or helpful hints to mill over.  If you are a "repeatedly check in on npc's and past locations so I don't miss anything" kind of player, like me, I pity you for you have a lot of people to talk to and a lot of dialogue to go over.  But you know, that's how it goes.  Its one of those things some of us both love and hate about RPGs; It can be genuinely rewarding to be thorough and check back with folks every now and again, but half of those NPCs gots nothin' new to say.

PLATFORMER ELEMENTS:  This game will have you running and jumping every which way, using your dexterity, brains and items to solve puzzles or traverse through the game world in general.  The puzzles certainly aren't the hardest brain-melting, callus-bursting mind teasers I've ever encountered, but some of them can be quite tricky and clever.  Still, nothing unfair.  If you wan't your character fully tricked-out by end game, you're going to have to deal with the cleverest and trickiest of them. 

PROGRESSION:  This game is built around progression gates.  You find an item, solve a puzzle or do someone a solid and your world opens up a bit.  You can go more places, do more things, survive new challenges and occasionally return to old haunts.  Tis a pretty common mechanic (if you say 'Metroidvania' out loud while you read this I will slap you through your screen).  What I personally love about this game is you can fudge things a little.  There are more than 1 or even 2 ways to solve some puzzles.  There are unusual (and probably unintended) ways you can use items and push/float/throw/stack things around to get the results you want.  There are a few progression steps I have been able to skip because I was a clever boy and figured out how to get to where I wasn't s'posed to get.  Luckily this didn't result in any game-breaking (a testament to good programming, I'll venture), but I did encounter one odd inventory/menu bug because of it.  Still, the gameplay rewards and sense of accomplishment far outweighed one little bug and a crap-ton of patience.  Speaking of patience...

EXPLORATION AND SECRETS:  I love a game that rewards you for poking around, keeping a sharp eye out and checking back every once in a while.  There are LOADS of secrets to discover and many totally optional areas you can only enter by returning to places you've been before.  This adds depth to gameplay and, sometimes, to lore as well.

INTERFACE:  The HUD looks good is pretty simple to understand, but the menus could stand a bit of polish, especially with respect to navigation.  Something to help keep track of quests might be nice too, but given the fairly linear style of the game, it isn't strictly necessary unless you demand to have your hand held.  Just pay attention to what people have to say and keep a notepad handy for when someone mentions something intriguing or important and you'll be fine.

ALL IN ALL:  What I really appreciate with Phoenotopia is its distinctive blend of flavors.  None of its components are new or done in an earth-shatteringly brilliant way, but it is a solid blend.  I get the feel that this is a passion project that has been in development for a long time,  done by folks who are paying homage to some great games by blending their key elements into a coherent, competent and FUN game.

PRICE:  As the cinemas in your area open back up, buy a movie ticket and grab a soda and a popcorn while you're at it.  You will hopefully be entertained for 1.5-4 hours, depending on the movie.  You will likely have spent more money on that than you will on this game. Phoenotopia Awakening is a gorgeous, intricately designed video game. It's something like a Zelda title infused with a certain amount of Cave Story and - somehow - a smattering of Dark Souls... but there's honestly nothing quite like it.

Phoenotopia started out as a Flash game on Newgrounds almost a decade ago. I think it's fair to say that the content appearing on Newgrounds during its heyday was... somewhat variable: a lot of games uploaded there were janky, forgettable or just plain bad, with a few gems standing out as interesting proofs of concept. And then there was Phoenotopia: innovative in its own right, but more than just a proof of concept - it knew its influences and could see a gaping void where a game of its sort really *ought* to exist. It felt like cheating to be given that game for free.

I was delighted to learn that a remake was in the works. The developer considers the Flash game a first draft, and having finally played the commercial release, I am once again blown away by the breadth and quality of the vision behind this project. Phoenotopia Awakening provides a fully-realised world with a far more substantial and expansive challenge than I had anticipated, even after fully expecting a far grander work than the earlier iteration of Phoenotopia.

Its dungeons are artfully designed, each one unique and interesting; its puzzles are similarly well-constructed, developing in complexity in a highly engaging manner; its combat, while not perhaps as fluid as I might have initially hoped for, proved extremely satisfying to master, such that I'm not sure in retrospect that I'd want any tweaks to it; there was that special sense of achievement at overcoming each of the later bosses that fans of the likes of Hollow Knight ought to appreciate.

The pixel art and music are utterly beautiful - I've been listening to the latter fairly obsessively over the last month, while the former shows a facility for colour that left me gawking in sheer wonder at several of the game's environments. In gameplay, world building and aesthetics alike, the level of detail is illustrative of just how much care went into this passion project.

The difficulty curve of Phoenotopia Awakening is smooth but perhaps a little steep for some. I enjoyed the challenge, but the game does include a decent range of accessibility options for those who would benefit from them. I loved every minute of my playthrough, and heartily recommend this game to any fan of classic Zelda, metroidvania, or well-conceived 2D action games generally.
