[quote]A review copy was provided by the developer.[/quote]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WIaNdSzBoyg
[h1] First Impressions [/h1] 
When looking into Phoenotopia: Awakening (PA), I saw that it was a remake of a free Flash game, one which I hadn't played before. That was launched mid-2014, and with Flash fading away, that may have inspired the developer to recreate PA for Steam. Looking at the trailers and reviews, it looked like a charming Metroidvania, and with a few years of experience to work off of, I hoped for an experience that would have buffed out any rough spots. Unfortunately, my mood soured with PA pretty quickly, in spite of the interesting premise. 


[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
There appears to be some discrepancy on how people would describe PA, whether it is or isn't a Metroidvania or if it's more of a Zelda II kind of game. Personally, I see it as a platformer that emphasizes exploration, dungeon-crawling, and speaking with NPCs, which is what I expect out of most indie adventure titles. However it'd be categorized isn't of much concern to me, as it doesn't change the experience, which on the surface level covers the checklist of things to include in a good game, but not in a well composed way. For instance, I've grown accustomed to chatting with every NPC I can a handful of times, happy to learn more about the surrounding area, rumors going around, and potentially pick up a quest. In PA, the processing of events seems to be fixed and linear, so that a specific NPC has to be spoken to first to trigger another one's dialogue option, which opens another possibility, and so on. This leads to backtracking and doing things rigidly, instead of allowing for more organic exploration and advancement in the game. 

However, what I disliked most with PA was the game's combat system, which is a common complaint amongst the negative reviews. If you play PA with all combat modifiers turned off, which I see as being how the game is intended to be played, swinging the bat drains stamina, even when only breaking boxes. Worse than that though, almost every action you'd take is based on this stamina bar: dodge-rolling, sprinting, throwing bombs, hurling rocks with a slingshot, etc. Your options in combat are limited, as all of them revolve around the same resource, stamina. You don't have a number of arrows and bombs that can be used as you see fit, using one of these draws from the same pool as the close-range melee attack. The only ones that don't rely on stamina are basic movement, jumping, and eating to heal. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2395994837
[h1] Controls [/h1] 
The control scheme gets fairly complicated in PA, so I won't offer a breakdown of them in this case. However, this in part is an issue I have with the game, as I don't think it was designed as ergonomically as it could have been. An example of this is the sprint mechanic, which isn't treated as a faster movement cycle you switch to when you're wanting to hoof it. Instead, it's like hitting the melee attack button, as Gail will sprint a certain distance after you hit the button, and you can't hold it down to make her run faster. Its primary use is for making longer jumps or dodge rolling, which you do by hitting the right button after you've hit sprint. It works, but it's not as satisfying as just having normal control over the PC's speed. 


[h1] Story [/h1] 
As the game begins, Gail rounds up the children of the village and dives into a nearby temple to check out a meteorite that fell nearby. Upon discovering what it is and starting to head back home, an alien saucer swoops in and kidnaps all of the adults, leaving behind only the children. It's simple and straightforward, but this is a good hook to establish the plot of PA, as there's important, personal stakes on the line. With so few things explained about the situation, players have enough room to speculate and guess what'll happen, as Gail heads out to follow the few leads available and try to find and rescue the kidnapped villagers. I'm curious how it all pans out, yet won't finish the game to find out for myself. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2395992949
[h1] Graphics [/h1] 
This is another example of an indie game that has great visuals, as I find the pixel graphics of PA vibrant and detailed. It's easy to determine what items are in environments, settings don't look tired and repetitive because the backgrounds have enough variance to look organic, and the layered environments give areas a sense of depth. Out of the graphics, the area that falls flat for me is the character models, as I find them easy to mix up. Were it not for such flashy hair colors, I think they'd blend together. 


[h1] Sound Design [/h1] 
When listening to PA's soundtrack, I'd say it's well composed. It covers a broad range of tones and tempos, which helps build different feelings about the environments Gail travels to. I'm a fan of instrumental music, so I can easily slip into it and enjoy myself. A simple downside is that many of them aren't very long, so they loop upon themselves fairly quickly. 


[h1] Pros [/h1] 
🌟 There are gameplay options that can be turned on and off to adjust the difficulty, to some extent. You won't be able to increase your HP or weaken enemies though. 
🌟 I found the visuals and story went well together, which both drew my interest in the first place and held my attention as I played. 
🌟 Based on the progression stats from the loading menu, there's quite a few secrets to hunt down. 


[h1] Cons [/h1] 
❌ Another problem in combat stems from how getting hit by an attack momentarily stuns the PC, and can lead into being juggled for multiple hits with no ability to dodge or respond. You'll only get invincibility frames after getting hit 3 times in a row, and with a starting HP of 30, a sizable chunk can be shaved off due to a chain reaction from taking only 1 hit. Due to this, the number of enemies is sometimes more of an issue than how strong they are. 
❌ It's not uncommon to find an item that seems pointless and will waste a valuable inventory slot, until you're able to do something with it much later. Also, with how many items there are to buy, some of which are required for progression, PA is rather tight-fisted when it comes to loot. 
❌ Not only is there no auto-save feature, you can only save at predetermined save points. This makes it easy to lose progress. 


[h1] Tips [/h1]
🔍 Don't hesitate to drop weak healing items if your inventory fills up, as a cooked item like fish is much more useful than raw berries. Also, when you get to Aria, buy at least 4 inventory slots. 
🔍 Since PA won't track information for you, it'd be worthwhile to either jot down notes or follow a guide to know where you'll want to backtrack and when. 
🔍 You can walk through bosses if they're not in an attack phase. This will be necessary in order to deal with their patterns and counter attack. 


[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1] 
Even though this is an indie title, I still have certain expectations when it comes to modern-day adventure games. Especially when it draws inspiration from other games and has the advantage of being a remake. Despite this, it doesn't have a map system or item/quest tracking, optional treasure items take inventory slots, you have to speak to specific NPCs at certain times to progress, etc. Overall, I find that the game doesn't seem well designed around its own mechanics. Simply switching stamina use for basic attacks on and off unbalances the game completely, leading it to either be significantly harder and more tedious, or making boss fights a cakewalk. Although it has charming visuals and some interesting ideas, it lacks a level of polish I'd require to stick it out, and isn't one I'd recommend playing.

This game is a true masterpiece. I'm not sure that I've ever enjoyed a game start-to-finish as much as Phoenotopia. The play style resembles a mix of Zelda and Metroid, with a story that is part Final Fantasy and Earthbound, all with a delicately balanced utopian/dystopian flavor... the result is something totally unique.

Every aspect of this game was done with excellence and care- the script was engaging and humorous (it was actually worthwhile to talk to every NPC, even as each typically had at least 2 layers of dialogue), the music was spot-on for each terrain, and the graphics were incredibly intricate in the pixel style. The physics are perfect- character movement is free and agile, and the ability to smack enemies across the stage with a hard strike never got old. The wide range of weapons, tools, and abilities lent itself toward an even wider array of tactics, and the primary healing mechanism (collection of various foods, which could be cooked to improve properties) was fun and engaging.

Perhaps most impressive is how enjoyable every minute of play truly was- it took about 48 hours over the course of a month or so for me to casually work through to the end without attempting to grind for every achievement (90% completion on the casual run, then another 4 hours to go back and get 100%). With every added ability/tool that allowed access to different areas within old regions, it did not feel like a grind to return; I enjoyed the opportunity to re-explore the past areas knowing there was some reward to attain (even if small). Part of the intrigue is the many layers of rewards possible- in addition to the standard units that increase maximum health/energy that are found in many games, there were a large number of additional abilities, tools, weapons, and side storyline tidbits that made each exploration interesting and worthwhile.

Well done, developers- I'll eagerly await the sequel, and hope you'll have the support needed to continue the story!

After finally finishing the game I can I say this is the best game of its kind I've played in about 15 years. This game leans heavily into exploration and gameplay and is fairly lite on progression (there's enough). 


[h1]Exploration (10/10)[/h1]
The way this game captures the feeling of exploration is unmatched. My last session was 17 hours long, and all of that time was pure exploration. If I had to guess 3 most important things, I'd say: big world, rewards for side tracking, no hand-holding (i.e. quest markers, maps, navigation). That culminates into you running around blindly, finding areas, solving puzzles and ALWAYS being rewarded. Most similar games screw up in 1 of those aspects.

I mentioned the game is "big", but it's done through world density rather than size (although size is respectable). Every area, house, NPC and object feels like it is worth interacting with and so far over half of all areas I visited featured at least one platforming section, hidden area or a puzzle of some sort.

"Big deal, lots of games do it" I hear you say. Well, that they do, Billy, but Phoenotopia has few key game design choices that make it feel more rewarding than competitors
[list]
[*] [b]Upgrades, Food and Money have value[/b]. Money is scarce and is used for many things(including upgrades). For most of your journeys your HP cannot be recovered in the most difficult sections, so upgrades that save HP, food that can restore it and money that can buy both always feels valuable. That means even if you complete a puzzle to find generic 30 coins or a piece of food it's still not a disappointing reward as it might be in a Zelda or Castlevania games.
[*] [b]Puzzles are numerous, while most are intuitive and fairly short (1-2 minutes).[/b] This might be a personal preference, but to me that meant I was never strained by them. They felt more like opportunities than 10 minute roadblocks. There are a few more difficult ones, but not enough to make them feel like a chore.
[*] [b] Game gives general directions, rather than specific instructions with GPS navigation.[/b] This took me years to fully appreciate, but when games have a map, navigation, quest markers and other similar stream-lined crap that makes my brain switch off as I go A to B for 60-100 hours. Streamlined content often makes me feel like I'm doing chores rather than exploring. This game has none of that - you find and solve everything on your own. The game only points you in general direction you should be going.
[*] [b]Puzzles disguised as metroidvania style ability gating.[/b] If you see a ledge you can't reach metroidvania design will lead you to believe you need an ability to reach it. Well this game mixes it up and half the time, places a puzzle instead. It still looks like an ability gated area, so figuring out that it is a puzzle is rewarding on its own, and solving it is twice as rewarding.
[/list]

[h1]Combat(8/10)[/h1]
A common complaint is unfair combat, which I can definitely see at higher difficulties. Your basic attacks include short reach melee and various ranged weapons, which all leaves somewhat defenseless for some time. There's no damage on-contact, so you can safely walk all over then as long as enemy attack doesn't connect with you.

[b]Enemies are easy to read[/b]. Main difficulty in fights stems from positioning yourself well enough to attack after enemy attack animation ends (which often leaves them too far to reach in time before next attack) and not get hit when next one starts. So far there was one exception: [spoiler]a teleporting enemy, which was more annoying than difficult due to need to chase and then risky attacks required...[/spoiler]
[b]Bosses[/b]are just as easy to read as normal enemies, but safely positioning yourself for an attack is significantly harder.

[b]Difficulty[/b]
To evaluate combat I first need to address the difficulty, which can range from casual game to unfair souls-like, due to the way difficulty scaling is setup. Honestly, I think these developers deserve an award just for taking the time to design difficulty settings, which are not just stupid enemy HP/damage multiplier.

There are 5 levels and I've tried 2 of them. 
[list]
[*] [b]5* difficulty(hardest)[/b] - Most actions drains stamina and food takes a while to eat. As you would imagine this makes the game feels like a souls-like, and if you have to fight multiple enemies it can feel like an unfair souls-like. If you're up against 3+ enemies you are very unlikely to avoid all attacks while attacking.
[*] [b]3* difficulty(medium) [/b] (what I play) - Basic attacks do not cost stamina and you can eat food from menu to skip the eating animation (this chops the difficulty in half). This makes the game feel more like a traditional platformer. You still take the same damage, but it's easier to fight enemies when you don't have to worry about basic attack stamina, or positioning yourself to eat safely. Both of those allow to play more aggressively, which changes expertise required in fights quite a lot.
[/list]

[b]So why 8/10?[/b]
This 1 enemy type cancerous. You wouldn't call it hard, it just slows you down... a lot. Luckily it's mostly localized in 1 area.

Few areas in game are annoying for combat reasons. In all cases enemies are still easy to read, but I faced a few situations where they felt impossible to avoid due to numbers.

[h1]Humor(10/10)[/h1]
This is subjective, but I figured I'd include it, because I loved it. The game features adult humor (contextual humor, no NSFW stuff), which ranges from comical life situations to subtle jabs at similar stories. For example: you find this band of musicians that pass a remark along the lines of "We found (girl's name) in a forest suffering from amnesia. Can you believe that?". This cracked me up, because that's exactly how a good portion of games start.


Other stuff that might interest you
[list]
[*] I love the style, but it's pretty subjective. Sufficed to say people often underappreciate the difficulty of making pixel art look good AND THEN making good looking animations.
The first animation I saw in game (yawning after waking up) made me smile. 
[*] Fluid controls. Character never feels awkward as they do in some platformers. It might take you a while to get used to button layout, though.
[*] Music. In general I don't dislike it enough to mute it, which makes it great in my book. I love a few tracks (like Boss music). Only exception is desert city theme music (often the case in other games too).
[/list]

Few minor negatives
[list]
 [*] Few minigames required for full completion (for full completion). Minigames rarely feel satisfying and this game is no exception. Yeah, sense of achievement an all that, but I don't play amazing games just to play some cheap knockoff minigame built into it.
 [*] Combat against multiple enemies (especially if those are flying enemies) can feel unfair. Jump attack has quite a long wind up and aiming projectiles leaves you defenseless against ground enemies.
 [*] 2 achievements that waste time, in this game's setting. It's a game that gives you little reason to play a second time, but achievements require multiple playthroughs. It's TECHNICALLY possible to do them in 1, but not in practice.
[/list]

In case my opinion about the game was not clear to this point. I think it's a masterpiece. I'll probably buy a random friend a copy, just to support these developers.

86681715.review:
This is the bastard child of Salt & Sanctuary + Stardew Valley that I never knew I wanted (yes, the original Phoenotopia came first, but I haven't tried it.)  Phoenotopia: Awakening is a sprawling, imaginative, platformer that strained my combat ability and frequently surprised me with its creativity.  Though it wasn't perfect, it was a good use of $20.

[b] The Good: [/b]

- Pretty sizable map that takes a while to explore.

- A lot of detail and content in a world that feels very lived in, with extensive side quests.  It's also pretty for pixel art.

- The universe merges scifi, post-apocalyptic, and medieval fantasy genres fairly well without taking itself particularly seriously most of the time.

- NPC dialogue is solid across the board and warrants a chuckle at times.

- There's fishing, and it's optional!  There's cooking, and it's... less optional!


[b] The Bad: [/b]

- Even basic attacks will throw you across half the screen.  Groups of enemies/bosses will often be able to chain hits or yeet you into hazards with little difficulty, which can get frustrating.

- Even though there's a ton of content left after credits, the actual postgame is poorly implemented.  Basically you get sent back to the room before the final boss and the world you walk around isn't any better than when you last left it.  [spoiler] Nothing resembles the victory cinematic, the people of your village that you set out to save are still missing with no path to rescuing them, the royal palace is still a warzone, etc. It feels like a third of the ending was hand waved away without the player getting involved or enjoying the results.  [/spoiler]  There is apparently a sequel coming out, so this may be alleviated.

- No minimap, which makes thorough exploration a little more tedious when you inevitably run around in circles.

[b] The Subjective [/b]

- Combat is punishing.  Poor timing or putting yourself in a bad situation will get you killed outright.  Bosses are hard.  Most healing can't be done on a whim (unless you choose to enable it in the menu.)

- There's a lot of backtracking as you unlock new abilities, pretty par for the course in this kind of game.

- Plenty of puzzles, ranging from "move the boxes around" to "find the right way to travel through this entire massive area with minimal use of the keys hidden throughout and one map hidden in the background."

- If you want tough platforming, you can find it.  For the most part it's not mandatory.

- Money feels precious; the game isn't too generous with it and you'll want to buy food, weapons, even inventory space.

If you're looking for a game to be in your top 5 ever list, I don't know this is it.  If you've finished Hollow Knight or Ori and want something else to scratch that explore/save the world/die frequently itch, this will do a good job satisfying that.

It pains me to give Phoenotopia a negative review based on a purely subjective experience. Objectively, this is a decent game, clearly with a lot of effort, skill, and love put in. The graphics are beautiful, the story is rich, the music is good, some mechanics are interesting (e.g. encounter transition mechanics). There are lots of interesting puzzles, good humor, and charm. And there are dozens upon dozens of hours of content (based on research I've done). Unfortunately, this research is second-hand, since personally I've abandoned this game after 6 hours. 

Why did I do so? The little things. There are just too many quality-of-life problems that might be endearing to the old school players of 90s RPGs, but are neither common nor really acceptable for a 2021 game. Such as: no in-game map (very unusual for a metroidvania, where backtracking is very common), no quest markers, and no diary or quest journal system. Unless you want to refer to guides/walkthroughts, you need to play this game with a pen and paper, and pay a lot of attention to the text, to remember where to go and what to do. Some puzzles also semi-softlock and require a full game restart to reset the environment, rather than just revisiting the area.

The other big issue is the movement and combat mechanics. It's just too slow and clunky. Fighting and dodging is hard (not because of challenging enemies, but because of crude and sluggish controls), the weapons are difficult to use, and the overall pace (both combat and progression-wise) seems just too slow/repetitive. Despite being a beautiful, well-crafted world, it just wasn't fun for me to stay in. 

Despite getting a lot of the "big picture" things right, the game just has too many small flaws and pain points for my taste. By all means, if you're the patient gamer willing to do whatever it takes to find a solution and overcome obstacles, pick up this game and don't let this review deter you, as you'll get many good hours out of it. For the less determined gamer, or someone more used to modern video game conveniences, you might find this game just too demanding.

The visuals are charming and the soundtrack is very nice. Puzzles were fun, although some were... challenging.

But at the end of the day this is a video game, a platformer with combat and RPG elements, and to me it fails to mesh everything together in a pleasant way.

Take the dash/run mechanic for example. In most other platformers you have a "hold button to run" a la SMBros, or "tap button to dash" a la MMX. This game combines both: you hit a button to dash, but then you have to hold it to continue running. This doesn't sound so bad until you find yourself in the heat of battle and suddenly your character dashes headfirst *into* the enemy instead of away from them. This was much less of a problem in MMX because in those games you could animation cancel your dash by letting go of the button and just hit the opposite direction on the d-pad. You can't do that here, as there is very little in the way of animation cancelling. Shot your crossbow? Wait until animation completes before you can jump or run, lol. There's also the very laggy aerial melee attack animation (as in, the time between you pressing the button to attack and the character actually swinging their weapon), the need to re-press the dash/run button after every jump, and the fact that they actually mapped the "aim crossbow" button to the dash button (at least on KB, which I am using because I have no good controller). Also, the melee attack range in this game is a joke; apparently you get a decent melee weapon later, but I didn't even get to that point before getting fed up with the awful controls. The end result is a platformer with unresponsive controls, and it really takes away from my enjoyment of the game when half the time I'm fighting the controls on top of trying to fight enemies.

And before I forget: it's 2021, I thought we were all past the water = death trope platformers used to have. I mean, I'm a *bad* swimmer, but even I wouldn't flail around like a moron every time I get into water higher than my waist.

TLDR: Great visuals and soundtrack, fun puzzles, but unresponsive controls and questionable design choices sucked a lot of the fun out of the game for me. In the end I uninstalled the game without getting past the second world area (desert), that's how much I was put off by the stupid controls. Very disappointed in this purchase.

85750376.review:
I honestly wasn't expecting the game to be as long as it was. Took me roughly 35 hours to finish it and I didn't even get to collect everything. I absolutely loved the minor things that Gail does. The little bop and yawn after you rest, the sounds she makes when she goes for the headbutt, and especially the random teleport collapse. All very cute.

That said, the game definitely could have played a bit better. I did enjoy playing through it but there was enough mechanics that irked me that made it frustrating at time. For starters, your sprint cancels if you fall off a platform or land a jump. It felt like an unnecessary mechanic and really should have just let you keep sprinting. Jumping was also frustrating at times since the direction Gail is facing is locked after you jump and you can't turn to face the other way mid jump. The game defaulting to no i-frames is also a really weird game design choice. If you aren't careful you could end up getting combo'd until you die. There are gameplay accessibility options that you can turn on and one of them is getting some i-frames after getting hit twice in succession but it really should have been the default.

As for non-mechanical things, the puzzles in the game were for the most part pretty simple or easy to figure out. There were only a few puzzles that actually required me to whip out a notepad to jot things down for. Nothing a bit of trial and error couldn't fix. The character dialogue was really enjoyable. I found myself actually laughing at some of the things that the NPCs said or did. The story was interesting but a bit lackluster and anti-climatic. I didn't realize the final boss fight was even happening because it didn't really give off a "final boss" vibe. I'm aware this is a remaster of the original game and there is an original Phoenotopia 2 so hopefully they'll remaster that as well to resolve the story.

The one thing that REALLY bothered me was the secret boss. I wanted to fight it but the game locks you out of fighting it until you have max HP and Stamina. There's in-game way to check which HP/Stamina upgrades you've found and needing to find all of them just to fight the secret boss seems like an excessive lockout. I really didn't want to go find a guide to get all the upgrades and go check each spot to make sure I had the upgrade.

Overall: 8.5/10. Despite the minor annoyances the game was still an overall enjoyable experience and I would 100% play a remaster of the second game if they ever did one. Definitely worth picking up if you want a game to kill some hours with.

85731124.review:
In my days I've played a LOT of metroidvanias. They're by far my favorite genre of game. I own probably most of the metroidvanias on steam. And throughout all of that, Phoenotopia: Awakening is probably one of the best ones I've ever played. It does some things better than some of the greats like Hollow Knight, Super Metroid, Ori. Of course all of those are greater in certain parts than this, that's for sure. But I think the fact that this game that's flown under the radar can-- in my opinion-- compete with the greats of the genre is incredible.

Pros:
+Art strikes a perfect balance between detail and simplicity with the art style. And it's cute as hell.
+Puzzles are great. There are very few times in the game where a puzzle is actually repeated. It always kept fresh. And for the most part they're good and have fun AHA moments. throughout the game there was maybe 3 puzzles that I couldn't figure out, and had to look up, and with only 1 of them did the solution not make sense.
+Music is pretty good. Not the best, I'd say others have it better, but they do a great job of setting the mood, and there's some tracks that are incredible.
+Above just about any other metroidvania i've played, it REALLY rewards exploration. There's been a lot of neat moments of exploring someplace and finding something neat, or exploring all the side paths.
+Character interactions are great, just about every npc has at least 2 unique lines that you can chat with them with. And there's a lot of NPC's
+A LOT of stuff. I'm about 35 hours in, and I just finished the final boss with 80% completion. And it's been fresh the entire time.
+There's a fishing minigame. As time goes on I think any games is incomplete if you don't have a fishing minigame.

Not cons, not pros: Some of these may be cons to you, but to me, they weren't.  But weren't pro's either
o There's no map. Usually that really sucks for metroidvanias for me, but as I kept playing the game I didn't really find that an issue. That's usually a lot of points off for me, but the levels and such are designed in a way it's very difficult to actually get lost (probably mostly because there's an overworld to go to different areas. But even in the most complicated areas i never really got lost.
o The story isn't incredible. It serves it's purpose well, but it's not especially hard hitting.
o Combat. It's very basic. You have smack, heavy smack, and then some side weapons that there's only really 2 that have much function in combat unless there's a puzzle element to a boss that requires using one of the others. There's also an energy system that I don't know if it added to the game. I won't say whether the game is better without it, especially because one can lower difficulty to minimize that.
o Grinding. I had to do very little, but it's still something that I needed to do at one point, and to 100% the game there's more to be done. I'm not putting this as a negative only because i had to do it so little. Otherwise exploration and side quests kept my wallet decently full.
o No quest tracker. This one is very close to being a purely con, but again, it never really was an issue for me.
o A purely personal one, but I think a smidge more lore would have been great. There's just still some questions and or details that I think would really bring the world just that step higher. There's enough details to get a nice bit of lore... but just a bit more would have been great. Maybe in the sequel that's probably going to happen?
o Difficulty. It was a very comfortable level of difficult for me, but I'm very experienced in these types of games, this may differ for you.

Con:
Aside from the ones that for YOU might be a con? None. A couple of things were close, but just... weren't enough of a problem to really be a con. This game is very well designed. If i had to pick something, some enemies were kinda annoying to deal with.

And finally to address some complaints that I've seen, and my perspective.
Combat is bad: It's a bit limited, but It's functional. It's roughest in the early game, but even then the short range and stamina didn't feel BAD. It's not like i kept accidentally running into enemies because the range is short, when you get hit you get knocked back, but especially if you learn to ukemi it's barely a loss of time. Juggling is very rare, and that usually happens when you let yourself get surrounded.

Enemies are tanky: I don't particularly understand this one. So long as you don't completely ignore weapon upgrades, i never felt there was a point where there was any enemy that took too many hits. Except maybe boars in the overworld encounters. They kinda take too many hits for being as slippery as they are, but they're also completely and easily avoidable. It's not like other ones where after a point all early enemies die from one hit, but I really wouldn't regard it as bad.

Movement is clunky: I didn't get this, sprinting and rolling takes a little bit of a learning curve, but soon enough it's easy. It's no La-Mulana or early castlevania level of jumping. There were only a few points where I felt it was a bit too hard to get the precision I needed with the movement options. otherwise I was able to be as precise as needed to properly platform as needed.

Grind: I only grinded at one point. There's only really one point of the game that gates continuing the main story behind money. I grinded a bit to get more money, and then never after that. I just collected, sold, and explored.

No Map: I didn't find it an issue as explained above.

Though a bit of disclaimer: Like I said, I've played a ton of metroidvanias, from the clunkiest to the smoothest, so in some of these my perspective may greatly differ from the other player's experience. But this is the game that I played and enjoyed, in my mind.

TL:DR: An absolutely incredible metroidvania, at least for me. 8.5-9.0/10 for a normal game, 10/10 metroidvania.

Phoenotopia follows in a similar vein to Hollow Knight, Rabi-Ribi, Sundered: Eldritch Edition, and, strangely enough, the Legend of Zelda 2. It beautifully (and I do mean that quite literally) ties together classic platformer mechanics with a tight control scheme, and many, many well thought out puzzles that are just the right level of difficulty, and keep you thinking throughout the whole game. Something rare in most any game these days.

I've seen some other reviews complain about how big hits send you flying, but that's actually a part of player skill, and it is explained multiple times by NPCs that you can negate this by hitting the dash button just as you are landing, and though the timing for this does need to fairly precise, the game does explain how to safely practice this skill until you've mastered it.

Did I mention the controls are tight? I'll be honest, slight gripe, everything is a little too tight. I don't really mean the controls, but the battles. Aside from most of the Legend of Zelda 2 style overworld battles, They're built like puzzles, which is great, I love the approach from a design standpoint, but once you figure out the puzzle, it's nice to have a little wiggle room for user error, which there is not much of for many of it's fights and challenges, especially along the main story line. They're tough, and while it's possible to beat all of them without taking any damage, some of them feel like a small Touhou fight. Even early on, the game doesn't hold your hand. That said, the puzzle mechanics to the fights don't get Rabi-Ribi levels of complex, and even when you do get hit, the fights are still rather doable, so long as you've figured out the patterns for the fight, and haven't completely refused to explore a little.

The game plays a lot like an RPG, and I was actually a bit surprised, given the overall style, to find that there is no leveling system, and you don't really need the Rin (this game's currency) you're awarded for fighting all that much either, so aside from the occasional need for item drops, the game actually encourages you to avoid fighting when possible, and it's here that this little gem shines. I thought I was being clever avoiding fights here and there, but it quickly became apparent that the levels are carefully designed and very well tested, actively rewarding you for what would have in any other game been seen as clever, out of the box thinking, both with the more obvious faster or better way around an obstacle or group of enemies, and collectibles often directly used for character upgrades. It's no ordinary metroidvania, and I love that it actively rewards you for gaming it.

Despite knowing that the difficulty the challenges in this game presents may seem daunting to some players, this is easily one of the best releases since Hollow Knight. Well done.

This is a 90% fantastic game, but the other 10% suffers from egregious design and implementation flaws that are so un-fun they mitigate the fun of the rest of the game.

The worst offender is a variety of enemies and dungeons which are designed around concise timing and dexterity (common for the genre), but are hindered by clunky controls that work against the player and inhibit the actions necessary.  Several "accessibility" options exist to scale the game's difficulty, but they all address parts of the game which can be adapted to with skill and none address the parts of the game that cannot be overcome as a result of the game's mechanics.

For example: you can turn on i-frames between hits to avoid being juggled by enemies, however the knockback many hits generate results in an input loss of roughly the same duration the i-frames are effective for, rendering them relatively pointless more than half the time.

Bottom line: fantastic game which works against itself in several infuriating ways to undermine itself.  I would not recommend the game based on this.

Phoenotopia: Awakening is the closest thing to a 2D Zelda game that I have played. That being said, it is also a distinct game. 

- In traditional Zelda games, to progress through the game, the player MUST have the proper dungeon item. They may also get optional pieces of heart to increase their life. 

- In Breath of the Wild, all weapons are optional. However, finding good ones doesn’t require the player to go out of their way. There are both heart pieces and stamina gems, but the way to obtain all of them is clearly from beating a shrine.

- In Phoenotopia, there are 3 types of "heart pieces", (one for energy, one for life, and one for optional weapon upgrades)  and most pieces of equipment  aren't required. There are also optional songs and optional battle techniques to improve combat prowess even more

 Because of this, the main focus of the game is on exploration.  Looking around for collectibles and solving puzzles is almost required to move on past the increasingly difficult combat challenges. Thankfully, it doesn't feel like a chore. Every treasure chest is cleverly placed, and each upgrade makes you feel increasingly powerful. The amount of content in this game is INSANE for a $20 game, and I have spent over 80 hours on the Switch version.

Furthermore, the graphics are good with smooth animations, it has a very good soundtrack, interesting story and worldbuilding, etc. If you enjoy the Legend of Zelda or exploration, this game is well worth the price.

This is a fantastic game that hearkens back to early SNES days with a ton of modern polish. This is my game of the year all things considered, but I can acknowledge that there are some issues that people will have with the game if you didn't grow up in that SNES era.

Examples include - no map system outside of the world map, "awkward" combat that takes getting used to, and the sprint-jump system. The combat and sprint system can be mitigated by experimenting with how it works and playing around it once you figure it out instead of trying to fight it. I personally didn't have a problem with no map, but I do wish they'd add one in an update as it would be a fantastic accessibility feature to help others.

I've outlined some tips farther down below to help you get around some of these issues!

I think the game's art direction, world building, general platforming, and music make this game a masterpiece for me. Every area has it's own music and distinct style which both fit together incredibly well. Some of my favorite tracks are "Boss Battle" "The White Towers", and "Merry Fellowship".


A few tips that I thought I'd share based on what people really dislike about the game based off other comments.

~Exploration~
- The game is focused on exploration and adventure over all other aspects! If you don't like to talk to NPCs or go off the normal path, the game probably isn't for you.
- The game has a ton of secret areas which are referenced by NPCs. You can miss ~50% of combat tools [spoiler] and these are not just health or stamina upgrades! Many are the best weapons/skills you can get in the game! [/spoiler] if you ignore NPCs hints or don't go looking for secret platforming areas.
- Enemies and combat stats seem to be heavily weighted towards getting ~25-50% of the hidden items in the world when you can. The early game is a little difficult, but if you explore and get 50-75% of items, it quickly becomes quite easy.

~Combat~
- 99% of enemies do not have contact damage. Your short range isn't as detrimental as you might think because you can get right on top of enemies and not take damage.
- Most enemies attack in front of them. If you're right on top of them, it's easy to jump behind them when their attack indicator shows to dodge the attack. Running backwards will likely get you hit, and the first few enemies (mainly frogs) are designed to teach you this mechanic.
- Like early 2d platformer games, there is animation cancelling when your jump attack reaches the ground. Try to implement hop attacks often! They do ~1.5x normal hit damage. Early game, a short-hop jump attack > either power attack or normal attack does a lot of burst damage with little stamina consumption. 
- If you really do not like the stamina mechanic, there is an option to turn it off in the settings. With jump attacks or charging, it is easy to play around it, but some people still might not like it.

~Sprinting/Stamina~
- You can perfectly control yourself in the air after jumping when NOT sprinting.
- Sprint jumps take you a fixed distance and should be reserved for combat ONLY. Maybe 1 or 2 jumps in the game require sprint. Otherwise it is just a massive lack of control and you'll be much better off doing a walking jump.
- Walking jumps are great for repositioning, dodging attacks, or doing general platforming.
-  Sprint jumps are a "get outta dodge" panic button in combat. Maybe you need to get away from an enemy quickly or get behind them. 
- In towns/general stretches of land, sprint > immediate jump > sprint immediately after landing > repeat is a fantastic way to preserve stamina compared to sprinting everywhere. You should be able to get the groove of this very quickly.
- Spamming normal attack in combat does good damage, but will run you out of stamina quickly. Implement the jump attack animation cancel into your fights!

Honestly this is one of the best games I've played and it was hard seeing the lower rating on steam due to people not experimenting with some of these mechanics and giving up early. Hopefully some of these tips help you on your adventure!

85225475.review:
I have spent well over [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/772534542744551455/802639034051461170/unknown.png]200 hours[/url] on this game since its initial launch, would be lying if I say I don't like the game. [b]10 out of 10 worth my time and money[/b].

[h1][TL;DR][/h1]
From world-building with the gorgeous pixel arts, soundtracks and clever NPC dialogues, to the exploration-focused gameplay that involves constantly finding well-hidden collectibles and solving unique puzzles, [i]Phoenotopia[/i] gives me the adventure I have always wanted from video games. It is definitely my personal favourite of all time.

[h1][Pros and Cons][/h1]
Pros:
+ 30+ hours of enjoyment, 50+ for full completion
+ Distinct- and beautiful-looking areas/[url=https://sillythewilly.bandcamp.com/album/phoenotopia-awakening-original-game-soundtrack]soundtracks[/url]
+ Hundreds of Zelda-fashion collectibles (equipment, techniques, heart pieces, chests, etc.)
+ Nimble main character and tight controls
+ Variety of combat options
+ Cleverly written dialogues (from comedic to deep and emotional, good stuff)
+ Great attention to details in world-building

Cons:
- Not enough maze-like areas/dungeons
- Game can get too easy if you are an avid explorer
- You can only hug Lisa once
- You cannot throw more money at Quells


[h1][Full Review][/h1]
This final section is where I elaborate on the [Pros and Cons] listed above. I also talked about [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/phoenotopia/comments/l1be7b/my_pretty_long_essay_about_why_i_love_phoenotopia/]why I [i]love[/i] this game so much[/url] on reddit, so give it a read if you're interested!

(I will simply refer [i]Phoenotopia: Awakening[/i] as PHOA from this point forth)


[b]Game Length[/b]

An average game of this genre can usually keep you entertained for 10 hours, and 15 ~ 20 if you are a completionist. The original [i]Phoenotopia[/i] (a free Web Browser game) is already this long, and PHOA is at least twice as substantial. I am pretty confident that PHOA is unrivalled in terms of quantity alone, but what about its quality?


[b]Different Aesthetics[/b]

The sheer variety is the strength of PHOA, and it is the main reason why exploration feels much rewarding here. In terms of aesthetics for example, all the areas have their color themes picked from all across the color wheel (see for yourself in the 2017 [url=https://phoenotopia.tumblr.com/post/162734499718/progress-update-zz]Dev Blog[/url]). It's hard to imagine how many colors they managed to fit in one game. Coupled that with the many fittingly amazing soundtracks? [i]Chef's kiss[/i]


[b]Numerous Collectibles[/b]

Having a big emphasis on exploration, PHOA has hundreds of collectibles scattered around the world as well. This game reminds me a lot of ALBW where I can find treasure chests and Heart Piece power-ups around every nook and cranny, and here you even have 100+ Moonstones to trade for tool upgrades, just like the Maiamai! Despite their differences in terms of genre, I am definitely getting a similar sense of wonder from both adventures!


[b]Movement and Control[/b]

Besides the unlockable [spoiler]Teleporters[/spoiler] and [spoiler]Trams[/spoiler], most of the time you will be traveling on foot, and I really like the movement system in this game. This may sound childish, but it feels surprisingly fun and free to run around towns and areas, to the point where we even have mini-games dedicated to that (called "Free Running Challenges"). It gets even more satisfying when you discover the few hidden movement tricks that let you almost run indefinitely, making normal running like its own obstacle course!


[b]Combat[/b]

The game has its challenging moments, but you'll probably have no trouble if you are patient enough. The essence of combat boils down to "how you approach the enemies", which is quite different to the reflex-tests that most other side-scrolling platformers offer. For example, if you are surrounded by a group of wild boars, you probably want to lure and focus on eliminating them one by one, as opposed to rushing in with your baseball bat.

It's also worth noting that enemies have no active hitbox unless they are attacking. So if you don't like close combat or throwing projectiles, you can literally run past pretty much all foes. Anyway, the game rarely forces you to use any specific weapon, and each weapon choice is good for certain situations (excluding the [strike]joke[/strike] ultimate weapon of course).


[b]NPC Interaction[/b]

Reading in this game is some of the most fun I've had. From the tutorial NPC that yeets you onto a bench to "teach" a technique, to the lore NPC that tells you about how the restaurant had to change its name after man-bear-wrestling became illegal for safety reasons, the writing in this game is simply full of life. Sure, some people may get overwhelmed, but it's not like you [i]have[/i] to read most of them to progress or anything, so I'll take this gladly!

Oh, and there are of course many Side Quests here. When it comes to quest rewards, you don't just get shiny new items, but also some of the best dialogues in the game too. While the bandit quest line might be fan-favourite to many, mine is the backstory of a nameless sentient robot (it kinda resonates with my mild depression, don't tell anyone). Needlessly to say, the game has a [i]really[/i] diverse cast of characters.


[b]Attention to Details[/b]

In addition to the assets and the writing, the designs are also pretty well thought-out. Treasures are in the form of antiques because you are exploring a ruin,  keys are one-time-use because it's a gemstone to be inserted, Prickle Fruit takes longer to cook because it's hairy and can be burnt easily like IRL, et cetera. All these small details may go unnoticed by many, but I argue that they do add up to help immensely in keeping this an immersive experience.


[b]Nitpicking (on level designs)[/b]

This game is [i]brimming[/i] with puzzles and riddles, and most of them are standalone with clues either next to them or right outside the room. There are many [i]many[/i] clever ones that I like, don't get me wrong, but I wouldn't mind seeing a few complicated Divine-Beast-like dungeons too.


[b]Nitpicking (on combat balance)[/b]

This is another part that "bad reviews" confuse me - The game is not really hard or unfair. Obviously, the more you explore, the more collectibles you find. Some come in forms of money (used for buying certain tools and inventory expansion), some come in forms of Heart Rubies/Energy Gems that raise your HP/stamina cap. If anything, you are near unstoppable when you can [spoiler]create explosion from thin air or regenerate health automatically[/spoiler]. The reward for exploration [i]may[/i] have empowered players too much near end-game.


[b]Not even Nitpicking[/b]

The animation when Gail hugs Lisa is so cute, and you only get to see it once per playthrough? [b]Blasphemy![/b]

Also, trust me when I say the most frequently asked questions from Discord are "Is any DLC planned?" and "When is the sequel coming out?". Guess it's safe to say that most of us are excited to see what's coming next from the team!

85122836.review:
5/5. A masterwork RPG. Worth full price.

Phoenotopia is big on exploration, lore, characters, puzzles and secrets, with simple yet engaging combat system. The world and its puzzles & secrets are laid out expertly. Its lore and visuals are consistent. The music is great. Everything is just perfect.

There is no quest menu. You must engage with the world and remember people, names, places and events to progress in the main story, and even more so for secret unlocks. As a vague example, you'd have to talk to a lot of people around town, who will give you nuggets of information that give you the general state of things. Guided by your own curiosity, you will use this information to find secrets and solve puzzles as you inch toward your goal, which often conveniently ties into the main story.

Combat is simple, but has depth due to the way you interact with enemies. Projectiles can be destroyed by hitting them. Enemies are not immune to environmental hazards. Enemies will perform certain actions, not at random, but depending on how healthy it is, what you are currently dong or where you currently are. Enemies aren't just damage soaks. They flinch and have knockback. Your attacks have weight. The gameplay begs you to outsmart the opponent. Enemies don't just touch you to damage you, they all have attacks that you can see and dodge. It just works.

The economy in this game is expertly crafted as well. They have a food and cooking system, that is actually VITAL. Inventory space is short, so you have to decide what you hold, use and discard. Eating is nuanced in an interesting way. Heavier foods heal for a lot, but take literal mid-combat seconds to consume, leaving you open while you try to heal. However, liquid foods, which are rarer to come by or harder to craft, can be consumed quickly, so they are better for combat, for example. Money is similar: it is scarce, making spending money a decision to weigh carefully. Do you want extra inventory slots or do you want that new weapon? Do I really want to spend money on this shady NPC who 'claims' to have useful information? You have to actually think about these situations! In most games, the economy is so bloated that you can throw money where-ever and it wouldn't even matter.

This game challenging and makes you think.

All that being said, difficulty may be a concern. If you're not one to pay attention or maybe you just forgot some key information, the lack of a quest menu may become a nuisance. Without the right leads in mind, you can easily get stuck, not knowing what to do, where to go, or how to progress, if you don't pay attention. Also, some combat scenarios can be very challenging. Keep in mind that there are a variety of perks you can enable to make the gameplay more accessible at any time. Settings, such as getting invicibility frames and having more stamina (you need stamina to attack or use abilities). 

---
Overall, I love this game. Definitely my favorite RPG to date. I've been a fan of the game since it was a Flash game on Armor Games. Since Flash died, this remaster is such a welcomed release. If you've played that version, note that this game is that, but with more features and new or reworked content, on top of the graphics update.

Also, its not a "metroidvania". Maybe in a very loose term... but do note It takes way more from Zelda than it does from Metroid or Castlevania. Phoenotopia is an open world, 2D action RPG.

This game delivers every promise it makes. It improves on every aspect of the original (flash) game and sets up a complete world to explore, with enough stuff to do to make it as rewarding as a game like this can be.

As an early follower of the creator's dev blog, I'm no stranger to the effort they've put into this and, in my opinion, it's been more than worth it. Congratulations to the team for making this jewel of a game!

The only downsides I can think of are probably regarding the difficulty of a few puzzles, which may seem a bit unfair if not properly equipped. Other than that, I have nothing to say.

The story may be similar to the flash game's, but this version has a lot more to offer. More characters, organizations, areas to explore, music, engaging dialogues... I played the flash version and this one surprised me a lot nevertheless. It's definitely something different.

With an expected minimum playtime of 30 hours and given the experience it offers, I'd say it's totally worth the shot. Buy this and spread the word, up until now it's been criminally overlooked.

85098787.review: Phoenotopia Awakening is basically a modern-day Zelda 2 if it were an actual Zelda game, filled to the brim with inventive puzzles, fun combat, and a metric ton of hidden things to find. I played it to completion when it released on Switch last year and it ended up being my game of the year. It's hard to get across just how much content there is to find in this game, and almost all of it is unique and fun to solve. The combat system starts out fairly basic with only a short melee attack, but your options expand as you find more weapons throughout the game. That main content of the game is the puzzles, and there's a ton of variety there. Every area manages to have new unique gimmicks; I found myself still being surprised with new puzzles even at the end of the game. For presentation, I really enjoyed the art style and the soundtrack is fantastic. All in all, this is one of the best indie action platformers I've played, and I've played a lot of them.

85094852.review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I] Smart Adventure Fans, Methodical Players[/i]	

[b] Summary: [/b]  

A game that seems destined to be on one of my overlooked games of the year list. It's not flashy when it comes to the trailer, it's art style is good but not eye appealing, and its first impression of gameplay doesn't seem to pop compared to other games. But I'm here to say that would be a mistake. Phenotopia Awakening is a game that understands how to assemble a series of mechanics together to make an alternative yet fantastic experience that will reward players who adapt to the game's mechanics. The dash having a real momentum really ups the challenge of both platforming and combat, and sub-weapons actually have strengths/weaknesses to make them actually sub-weapons (and not abusable). Combat can be tricky if you try to fight recklessly, and the game rewards you using your mind rather then your reflexes in many cases, which is really nice to see. Combine that with a great variety of different puzzles and combat scenarios, and you have a game that you can bite into.

The story does well in highlighting the world and not making it all about the protagonist, but actually feeling like she's a part of a huge adventure that happens in conjuction with other's stories. Granted, you may get bogged down in some of the text (there's a lot of talking here), and if you're someone who needs action every couple of minutes to feed your adrenaline addiction, this is not the game for you. It's a game where you will have to explore, find a side story, maybe do some grinding to get some money and food, and then figure out exactly where to go next. When the world opens up, man does it open up, to the point where it can really feel a little bit overpowering. With that said, it's a game that you can easily get lost in, wondering where the time went.

Give it a try, and you'll find a game that you'll want to see where it ends up taking you. 

[b]Gameplay Footage and Video Review:  https://youtu.be/n9H18rAmHa0 [/b] 

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] Strong alternative gameplay that relies on smart mechanic design in order to provide a challenge, rather then focusing on reflexes/reaction.
[*] Puzzle/Level Design is some of the best in the genre, having a variety but also actually making you think alternatively about your tool set.
[*] The best word to describe the game: clever. 
[*] Difficulty is challenging without being unfair. 
[*] Controls are purposeful in the right ways: forcing you to adjust to them without having variance.
[*] Lot of content here, chunky game that doesn't have a lot of bad meat on its bones (no real filler).
[*] Side-stories and missions are a blast and can lead to some hilarious/cute moments.
[*] Game uses it's presentation well to set up good moments and sound design complements the game rather nicely. 
[*] Feels like an adventure: a lot of games miss this lately and it helps that the game's events all feel of the same world and down to earth.
[*] Wonderful music that does well to setting the mood. 
[*] Good selection of accessibility options to help players without feeling like handing them the farm.
[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*] A lot to take in and you constantly end up getting lost. A game that at times I really feel like I needed a screen dedicated to quests/side missions/map.
[*] It does take some time to get adjusted to the different gameplay style at play here, and if you're stubborn, you're not going to have a good time.
[*] Every now and again you're going to need to grind for food/resources and at times it can get a little annoying. 
[*] Would like to see steam cloud saves implemented in the future.

[/list]
